reviewText: it was good but not as good as they made it sound.on the cover, there were many flattering adjectives used  to describe  this movie. I think they fell short.1-intense. this wasn't exactly  a war movie or a psychological thriller, so no.2-spectacular-yes-there were some great visuals and neat ideas.3-ground breaking. no. while the movie was very pretty and  very full of  great science stuff, there wasn't anything going on I haven't seen before.4-visually stunning-yes. this movie was full of "lord of the rings" worthy graphics with the awesome epic scale back drops and what not. it is very beautiful for many scenes and is pretty for  stretches sometimes adding to the overall entertainment and artistic value.5- mind blowing-no. it takes a lot to really blow a mind. while there are a lot of unexpected things going on. i'd call it more ironic than mind blowing. there were a few places that made me go, "whooooooaaaahhhhh, dude!" but no mind blowing.the cover also says he will "question everything he knows". that is true.so I was waiting for a big ending like say any of these movies...."planet of the apes", "total recall", "matrix revelutions "  "death race 2000", "1984" , "a midsummers night dream", "2001: a space odyssey" or "fight club". of course, I cant tell so you will just have to watch. its worth it.,this is morgan freemans third movie I know of where he gets to be a  great mind. the others are Lucius fox from the second batman trilogy and  when he played  GOD  in " bruce almighty".  this character is Morpheus like. Morpheus is the black guy in the "matrix" movies.on the cover, it says that tom cruise finds a beautiful stranger. the chick he's already with was very  very pretty. she had a nice body, not trashy, but nice. she had really pretty eyes and a heart melting smile. what did he even need this new woman for ? someone was mixed up there. I did not like that part.this movie is about a guy who can pilot spacecrafts in a post apocalyptic earth. THINK  "terminator" meets "top gun".all in all its pretty good. it made my top 85 movies of all time list.its a lot better than a lot of the junk that's been coming out lately. so its refreshing and fun.one mistake that was made is that sometimes when they show tom cruise flying around nearby wreckage to repair drones, the wreckage is of new York and sometimes Washington DC. but he's never gone long.
summary: a refreshing and fun science movie.

reviewText: I missed Oblivion in the theaters so today I got a RedBox rental. According to what I've read, and the rental dvd menu, there are special features… but none of the three versions sold at Amazon list anything at all!I sometimes find the extras to be the best part of a movie purchase and "Oblivion" would be one of those for me.Visually interesting but with endless plot holes such as contamination concerns (but you never saw Cruise taking any precautions- except an ordinary shower when he got home). What's to be concerned about? Earth was destroyed but various structure still stand, maybe buried under a LOT of soil, but standing- yeah, right.I think I figure out the alien angle before it was revealed, stupid aliens usually did a sloppy job of tracking Cruise- almost laughable.I may buy a copy someday, there is a visual appeal if you check your brain at the door, but I'll need some of those extras I've heard about and I don't see them here.

reviewText: American actor Tom Cruise plays character Commander Jack Harper. Jack lives solely to repair flying drones that hunt down and terminate all alien life forms remaining on planet earth after an attack and war with them that has left our planet mostly scorched. Jack isn't alone with his quest. Living with him in his perfect high-rise in the sky is beautiful Victoria played by (for me newcomer), English actress Andrea Riseborough. She is his companion and helpmate to keep the drones flying and in working order. Victoria loves Jack. They make an effective team.Tom Cruise's acting and that of the entire cast (including American actor Morgan Freeman and Danish actor Nikolaj Coster-Waldau), is excellent, compelling and solid. "Oblivion's" cinematography by Claudio Miranda is gorgeous with beautifully filmed surreal landscapes. It wow's you with excellent special effects, including scary flying terminator drones and Jack's really cool personal spaceship. All interior scenes of a devastated past world are expertly created by art director Ronald Reiss. Because of this "Oblivion" has a believable feel to it at all times."Oblivion's" story line is the best part about this film. On it's surface it appears as a flashy Sci-Fi film. But it's much more then that. It's a deeply thought provoking tale about obsession, love and loss, fear and longing, lies and deceit, and cellular memory. At it's core "Oblivion" is a human drama about humanity and the essence of who and what we are. Questions about mans eternal soul came into question while I was watching this film. I enjoyed this refreshing brain tickler for a change from all the heavy action films that have been out of late. "Oblivion" at it's heart a love story. It's quality is higher.As many people know, all good stories have already been told. Now it's up to today's writers to find new ways to re-wright these stories. To re-package and present them to us as freshened up new stories. I think writers (Michael Arndt, Joseph Kosinski and William Monahan), did a fine job repackaging many previously used ideas in this screenplay. "Oblivion" is based on an "unpublished" graphic novel by the same name by Joseph Kosinski.Parts of this story were for me predictable, but a lot was not. Sometimes it's okay to think you've figured things out in a story. To believe just for a moment that you might know what will happen next within the plot line. Then be right enjoying the satisfaction of seeing your guess unfold before yours eyes just the way you were hoping it would. Or like with me being totally wrong in my guess and loving my mistake. "Oblivion" has a few surprises too.Also, I love "Oblivion's" beautiful original Motion Picture soundtrack. It is co-composed by Anthony Gonzalez and Joseph Trapanese. Susanne Sundfor of M.8.3. preforms it's hauntingly beautiful theme song.You won't be bored in this film. I have now seen it twice, and the second time was even better then the first. I highly recommend this film to all Science Fiction Fans. You will enjoy this one. Enjoy!Release Date: 19 April 2013Running Time: 126 minutesRated: PG-13 for brief strong language and some sensuality/nudity but tastefully done.American Science Fiction/Action Adventure/MysteryGrade: A-
summary: 4 1/2 STARS ~ "Excellent Science Fiction Film Hits the Mark!"

reviewText: This is a glossy scifi flick with the obligatory twist toward the end.  Tom Cruise gives a standard, decent performance, and everyone else is fine.  He's of course far too old for his work/love partner in the movie, but that's standard Hollywood protocol.  (A female actor of his same age would be considered far too "old", for some reason).  Morgan Freeman, despite earning a spot on the poster/cover, has a very small role.Everything looks great, the movie moves along at a pretty brisk pace, the twist isn't exactly jaw-dropping, but it provides something to do in the last third of the story. (if you've ready any amount of scifi short stories or pulp novels from the 60s - 80s that owe any kind of debt to Ray Bradbury or The Twilight Zone then the twist feels very standard, but I don't hold that against them).  I also don't think the purpose of the twist is to amaze anyone, it's just a plot point.This isn't a bad movie at all, and I'd say it's pretty enjoyable.  I love big spectacle scifi flicks, so for me this one was good enough that I'll probably watch it again at some point.

reviewText: Very good science fiction movie, with beautiful effects and great acting! Of course, many scenes were made with a lot of help of computer and graphics, but that's the beauty of using the technology to create something great. I personally expected some more deep story line. For me it was similar like The Matrix. Just in The Matrix human's don't even realize there was a war and in Oblivion they believe they have won the war but they have to leave..One of the things that really mesmerised me was the house where the main characters were living. Amazing house with even more amazing pool. I wish to have such living place for myself:)This movie raised me a question about what we believe to be true. Do we really know that something is true or we are just taking the things other people or authorities are telling us and considering them to be true? As you'll see in the movie, there is no true, there is just a created reality we are living in. Even though the scenes in the movie are science fictional, the concept of human life is a reality which is happening around you every day just in different forms.
summary: Oblivion. How much do you believe what they are telling you?!

reviewText: I've read some rather pointed critique about this film, however I found the film entertaining and although they sometimes "give the plot line away" in still delivers a couple of decent twists and surprises. There are precious few decent sci-fi films today, so against this sad background I found Oblivion to be a refreshing and positive experience. The story is plausible and the pacing is good. Tom Cruise may be a wacky person off-screen but he continues to deliver some very credible performance in exactly the way that Bruce Willis does not (try watching "A Good Day to Die Hard" to see how far Bruce has fallen from his "Twelve Monkeys" days). So kudos to Tom Cruise, the supporting cast, the story, the photography, special effects and the Director for pulling off a complex film. I've watched this film 3 times and it still pleases - few films do that for me. I find techno-trash films like Prometheus to be depressingly stupid - Oblivion was a really nice surprise by comparison.

reviewText: Oblivion is the ultimate Hollywood movie wet-dream: horse manure script, an acting-free zone, no story-line worth a mention but... incredibly beautiful CGI. It's probably worth watching just for the visual images created inside a cloud's worth of computers, so long as you can switch off all critical faculties and pretend that you're watching a montage. Otherwise this movie is just an infantile and irritating waste of time with more plot holes than a truly perforated Swiss cheese (and far more odiferous). But really, the CGI is amazing.

reviewText: I am not a fan of Matrix Sequels or Inception. I am, however, a fan of 2001: A Space Odyssey. That being said, the multiple dimensions, duplicate beings, aliens or humans question, time/mind travel galore and related ambiguities of 'Oblivion' irritated me. On the positive side, the reason I didn't give it one star, but rather two stars, is some of the visual and plot similarities to seventies space movies, such as A Space Odyssey.To be fair, if you like to be left guessing at what is real or not in the movie, and are a fan of the movies I mentioned above, you may like this. There are parts that are comically far-fetched, and I must admit, I didn't need to understand those because they must have known it would be funny (we should hope).****SPOILER ALERT: The thought of thousands of Tom Cruises roaming the earth is a plot twist that I would not like to ever see in real life -  as one of him is enough for the world to handle real-time. Also, Melissa Leo as a coquettish southern space-station monitor who is actually a hologram for a hexagonal space god was a bit over the top (not a good use of even slightly hinting at 'HAL' in 2001: A Space Odyssey) :P

reviewText: I neglected to see this in theaters because reviews were mixed and the word-of-mouth that came to me was that it was Ok-to-Good. I regret not seeing it in theaters because I think this movie is underrated. It's a shame it under-performed at the box office. I suspect it will build up a nice following over time. As everyone seems to agree, it's visually outstanding. Acting is consistently good. Tom Cruise really is a fine actor and I think this is a terrific performance, subtle and restrained and just right. There are some elements that are awfully reminiscent of other science fiction movies, but it didn't distract at all from my enjoyment. There is an almost obligatory chase sequence...He's flying through some kind of big indoor space chasing and being chased and shooting at things, then squeezing through a tight spot to exit..I could have done without. Also, as much as I respect and admire Morgan Freeman, I'm wondering if it's possible WE CAN GET A FREAKING MOVIE WITHOUT MORGAN FREEMAN. Anyway. The movie has a fine twist to the plot that I didn't see coming. (It's clear that SOME kind of big plot twist is coming, but I wasn't at all sure of what it would be.)I'm sure I'll watch this again and am happy to recommend it to my friends.

reviewText: I expected a little more from this duo of Tom and Morgan.  They did an admirable job though, given the emotionless narrative of this futuristic story.  There just wasn't enough meat on this hog.The quality of the image and sound were very good though.  A blue tinted world, cold and foreboding, but still managed to eek out enough flesh tones for our benefit.  The sound was impressive, although again, it was lacking much emotion.Here's my big issue though...  Who came up with the original score?  It was worse than elevator music in a retirement home.  Harsh, brassy, and juvenile.  I mentioned an emotionless story?  Well, you got an emotionless series of background tracks too, baby!  Sympatico with our story here.There was potential though.  Some moments of untapped human drama.  Some doors left unopened.  In a way, this film serves as a reminder that you should run with tears, if tears make a story better.  You should build sympathetic characters, worthy of our care.
summary: Story quality bland, media quality good

reviewText: Oblivion is what science fiction should be.  It is about an idea not about action.  It is a story that makes you think.  Spoiler alert: We never see the aliens.The mystery  and discovery aspect of the story makes it easy to ignore that water is about most abundant compound in the known universe, so there is no need for aliens to take it from our planet. But the nice thing is that is not important.  It is just a tool being used to tell the rest of  a far more interesting story.

reviewText: Oblivion is a movie that projects great expectations, delivers even greater CGI (its smoothless and does not detract from the movie as some CGI in other movies has a propensity to do); however the ending causes this film to fall quite flat on its face. If there is one major fault with Oblivion its that there is a sense that it draws far too much on past Sci-fi movies (I found myself comparing particular scenes with previous movies - some now quite dated - and such reminicising drew me away from the premise of the movie itself) with the ending (no-spoiler here) pretty well much a re-make of a well known, but now quite aged, sci-fi movie (and thus a real dissapointment).Oblivion is an enticing journey into a post (dare I say) apocalyptic earth where mankind has truimphed over an alien invasion and Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) is left behind with his 'partner' as a cleanup/srvice 'mechanic' of giant sea converters. I am not a particular fan of Tom Cruise however here he harks back to his better days of acting and carries this film with a degree of aplom. Like other reviews here, I agree that there is far too little exposure of humans and how they have coped with life in this new earth and much more could have been done to explore this aspect, furthermore I was very dissapointed at the 'Alien' content and the ending of the film reinforced this, as in how they, the aliens, were portrayed.Oblivion started well, built at an excellent rate, maintained my interest - and then suddenly fell completely on its face at the end :( (hence only 3 stars and 2.5 of them are for the CGI and the futuristic technology). Oblivion is still a good movie to see, however in my 'humble' opinion its not a GREAT movie - watch it, enjoy it, just don't have too many great expectations (sic).

reviewText: Let me first say that I thought directorJoseph Kosinski'sTron: Legacy was abysmal. And apparently, a sizable portion of critics and audiences shared my opinion. But there were moments watching that I could not help but be impressed. Kosinski has a great visual eye, and shows mastery of lighting and framing. There are scenes in the film of startling beauty, like, "Wow. This movie is actually not ALL bad." Colour me intrigued. What else could this guy do?When he was coupled with arguably Hollywood's biggest movie star -Tom Cruise, a great supporting cast - includingMorgan FreemanandOlga Kurylenko, a bigger budget, and a promising script based on a six-page graphic novel treatment he penned, I was ready to give Joseph Kosinski a second chance.I saw Oblivion. Let's see what I thought below.Movies live or die on their casting so let's talk about that first. I understand the doubts about Tom Cruise, but really, there's no need for that. Put aside your thoughts about his personal life; the couch jumping, Katie Holmes, and all that. The role of futuristic drone repairman Jack Harper is quite possibly among his finest. Cruise shows he has a real screen presence, which, when combined with his roguish charm and charisma, results in a surprisingly sympathetic and impressive performance.Cruise's character is onscreen 90% of the time, so his performance is a big factor in the film's power. I can safely say that Jack Harper managed to be interesting, cool, and emotional without being over-the-top or sappy. Kudos to you, Tom. You might not be the finest of actors, but you're always fun to watch.Olga Kurylenko andAndrea Riseboroughboth give excellent performances as the films two female leads: respectively, the mysterious crash-landed astronaut Julia, and Jack's conflicted co-member Victoria. While Kurylenko's character brings the love interest and the mysterious flashbacks, Riseborough's Victoria is much more interesting and strong, plotwise. in the supporting cast we find Morgan Freeman, who is his usual awesome self as Malcolm Beech, one of the few remaining humans on earth; andNikolai Coster-Waldau, who brings the muscle and the beard factor to the game. Fine roles, all round!And here's another reason to watch Oblivion. Oblivion has the finest cinematography I have seen in a film this year. Echoing Lawrence of Arabia and 2001: A Space Odyssey, the stunning landscape of Iceland comes to vivid, awe-inspiring life with a minimum of CGI and a maximum of practical effects, camera tricks, and good ol'fashioned location shooting. Crumbling volcanos, vast mesas, winding canyons, valleys, endless plains, shifting deserts, dizzying peaks, and open sky are all beautifully shot, and, with a bit of CGI touch-up, become the alien-ravaged world of 2077. Seriously, see this in IMAX and you will not be disappointed. Oblivion is a veritable FEAST for the eyes.The costumes and tech and equipment are amazing as well. Kosinski chose to go for a more practical route here, and the extra work pays off. The world of Oblivion reminds one of an Apple Computer or theStar Trek (2009), but there are telltale signs that this is a lived-in, breathed-in, realistic world. Jack Harper's white costumes bears stains and grit; his chrome gun is scratched a little bit; his baseball cap is faded. Malcolm Beech's leathers are functional and weathered, while the garb of astronaut Julia is pristine grey and follows the clean lines of NASA. Form follows function, as Oblivion designer David Simon says, and so Oblivion's equipment - the drones, the planes, the guns, the motorcycles, the clothes, the beds, the electronics, even the sound of the tech, is all designed for maximum realism. But that's not to say it doesn't look cool. It does.I applaud Joseph Kosinski for his restraint when it came to CGI, and his use of practical sets and props. Here's to more in the future.Now, shall we talk cons? Oblivion borrows from too many movies to list. I see a bit of Moon here, Logan's Run there, a little of Star Wars there, is that a Solaris reference I spy? As original as Oblivion may seem, it may all be superficial - just on the surface. The story has been done plenty of times before, just not with this incredible cinematography and eye for detail. The climax was slightly "out there", and didn't reeeally fit the rest of the film tonally, but Tom Cruise's memorable one-liner is enough to make it worth it all.In conclusion, Oblivion is one of the best science fiction films to come out this year. But it's a good thing not many sci-fi films DID come out in 2013, because Oblivion is not as epic or original as it might want to be. That's not to stop the great acting, explosive action, great sets, costumes, and cool tech, and cool M83 score from letting you have a great time at the movies. My rating? Four and a half drones out of five. But why don't you watch it and see for yourself?P.S. Remember, the like/dislike buttons are NOT for saying whether you agreed with the reviewer or not, but whether the review helped you decide to buy the product. If you do not agree with the reviewer's opinion, use the comments section for that. Cheers!

reviewText: The best of standalone Tom Cruise has all been sci-fi in the last 10 years. Think about it. Ignore MI, which is a franchise. Now we are left with a string of hit-or-miss movies featuring old man Cruise struggling to look 25 after thousands of dollars invested in plastic surgery. Starting with Minority Report and continuing with War of the Worlds, Cruise has evolved into a sci-fi icon of sorts, very much like latter-day Charlton Heston. With Oblivion, which is essentially Top Gun plus 100 years of high-tech breakthroughs, the actor has come full circle.The SFX are what you would expect from a movie with a $120M budget and two A-list stars. A visually stunning earth home that sits right above the clouds is where most of the melodrama takes place. Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) and surrogate wife Victoria Olsen (Andrea Riseborough) exchange smooches, awkward glances, and plenty of scenery chewing dialogue before Julia (Olga Kurylenko) intrudes to form one dysfunctional love triangle. At this point, I could only hope that Jack would throw Victoria off the side of their home in a sort of futuristic nod to Captain Stabbin, but the soon-to-be ex-surrogate wife is dispatched via droid instead.Gaping logical flaws abound. Again, the home that is the setting for 2/3 of this film is situated above the clouds. With no guard rails. What if a strong gust of wind came and dragged one of the main characters off of the improbable structure? Also, I am pretty sure that in the next century, Earth's Stratosphere will still be pretty freaking cold! The surrogate couple swim around butt naked in their attached pool, while the accompanying outdoor temperature is likely below -60*F. Ice skating in Eskimo gear would be more reasonable.There is some business with clones that I could not understand. Morgan Freeman fails to impress. Olga keeps her shirt on. Combine Moon and Prometheus and you will arrive at Oblivion, which is ultimately too milquetoast to leave a lasting impression. This is "conservative" sci-fi. Nice haircuts, just-ironed uniforms, and staunch patriotism give off a Jetsons vibe. But the overall flick carries as much depth as a puddle, which does not make for good post-apocalyptic cinema.
summary: 3rd in a Trilogy, if You Count Minority Report & War of the Worlds

reviewText: I personally don't understand why this movie got bad reviews in the beginning. This was really a very intelligent and well done Sci-Fi Affair . No, it wasn't a action movie and I loved the fact it wasn't. In Fact it was a very intelligent complex well written story. I thought Tom Cruise's perfomance was one of the best he's had in along time. He actually had emotion and did seem vunerable and unsure of himself. I think any person that is intelligent and like challenging stories should see this. What it basically comes down too everything he knows is wrong. And why is everything in the state that it is in today is one big question. But as the movie progresses it give us all the answers we are looking for. The film isn't set up in a heroic type nature or action adventure type. Its about a man that is a technician and honestly just has bad days at work. And his quest to find the truth and to deal with the situations as they come up. Which is a rare style in this day in age for cinema. M83 did a great job with the music score it brought the film out. Instead of just playing as background music like most films. The score made the scenes more emotional and important. The visuals were astonishing and very uniquie like a tron or ridley scott affair. Joseph has his own style like Ridley Scott which is rare in the industy of todays american cinema. I really can't wait to see what he comes up with in the future as well as the next Tron adventure.----------
summary: A CroSS between VaNilla Sky and Ridley Scott.

reviewText: I was expecting so much more from this film, but since it let me down so much I won't spend much time with it.I'm a Tom Cruise fan, but this is not one of his better films.  It's okay--Tom Cruise  being Tom Cruise in a lackluster walk through of the movie.  I think he saw the boredom of the story at hand, but was anxious to collect his paycheck on the way out.The story has potential, but this was not fully realized by the screenwriters.  After  a while I found myself saying lines before they were said and predicting what would happen next.  Nothing too original here.Set and effects were okay, but we've seen it all before in better films.  Fairly dumb action sequences.  This is a film with a lot of gaps in logic where some things occur to show technology of the future, but then don't work later to show how heroic our hero is.I won't discourage anyone who is a sci-fi fan from seeing it, but I'm not going to say it's a must see.  I would have been better off watching something else on this movie night.

reviewText: Oblivion is undoubtedly a "homage" film.  This doesn't necessarily have to be considered a bad thing.  While it certainly is lacking in the originality department, it more than makes up for that with the enthusiasm it has for the movies it borrows from - specifically, late `60's and `70's sci-fi.  After the cheesiness and saccharine of the `50's, sci-fi took a side path into journeys of discovery and pondered the mysteries of the universe.  Film's of the time - notably 2001: A Space Odyssey - were less about action or horror and more about capturing the public emotion present in the years after the first man landed on the moon.Oblivion captures that spirit perfectly.  Considering it takes place on the ruined planet Earth, this is no mean feat.  That the film doesn't focus on the wreckage of humanity, but the wonder of what's been preserved goes a long way to keeping the focus on the wonder of the universe.  The color pallet is saturated with sunlight, a stark contrast to more dark and grimy post-Alien era of sci-fi films (the recent Prometheus comes to mind).  The architecture is cleanly designed - clearly, Apple Corporation's visual sensibilities will stay with us until 2077. All this serves to create a world that wants to be viewed and explored - not hostile and alien, but familiar and welcoming.Everyone will identify with Jack Harper, then, when he feels reluctant to leave.  Harper (played by Tom Cruise) is a maintenance tech on the vast structures that siphon water and useful materials from the barren rock that was once the planet.  He and his partner Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) are only two weeks from being able to pack up and leave to rejoin what remains of humanity on the "Tet", a sort of interplanetary ark.  Evidently, although the human race won the battle against whatever alien race menaced it, it left the planet totally unusable.  While Victoria is eagerly awaiting their call to leave, Jack is not so sure, his hesitance prompted by his discovery of a small oasis hidden in a mountain range that he frequently spends the night at against Command's orders.Amidst Victoria's feeble reassurances to Command that they are both still an "effective team", there is sense of something wrong.  Jack has continual flashbacks to a time before the world ended (a time he should not have been alive to see) all involving a mysterious woman.  As sci-fi tropes demand, as Jack is out on a maintenance run, an unidentified ship crash lands near him, and he finds her body in stasis in the wreckage.  Needless to say, not all is as it seems, and Jack's position slowly begins to unravel as he finds out he has been misled.No, it's not exactly original, but sometimes originality isn't necessary.  Oblivion walks in the path left behind by previous cinema heavyweights, but it does so with a vigor and pace that keeps the audience engaged, even when we see the twist coming miles away.  There are a few weak spots - while Cruise does a good job acting, his lines are often comically stilted.  There's a slight cheese factor here.  More demanding science fiction aficionados will find a great deal of plot holes as well, although many are closed up before the film's end.  Let's just say a lot of things aren't supposed to make sense at first.Setting that aside, Oblivion is a movie that does its predecessors proud.  With excellent visual effects, competent acting, and appealing callbacks to the golden age of sci-fi, it's enough to make you feel like the summer movie season is already here.
summary: An excellent throwback to the science fiction of yesterday

reviewText: Oblivion is a visually appealing flick with a strong bias toward lifting elements from sci-fi that did it better, and thankfully those movies didn't try to cram the whole kitchen sink into two hours. The action sequences were mostly good, though sometimes hokey ("I'm a droid with frickin' lasers, so naturally I'm going to come alongside your craft and ram you!" <-- seems legit). In the end, Oblivion left as many questions open as it answered and it sailed too close to the sun. I pray the open loops are not entry points for a sequel, it wasn't polished enough for folks to get excited about the prospect.Then again, Hollywood's not known for its good sense. (See: Grown Ups 2, Extra Excrement Edition)
summary: Mom, I Made A Sci-Fi Flick That Steals From All the Other Ones!

reviewText: I was prepared, after Minority Report, to be grudgingly impressed with Tom Cruise working in sci-fi. I was prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt. Unfortunately, the writers on this one were purely awful. So while it's a very pretty film indeed, it has plot holes big enough to fly a spaceship through, and that ruined it for me.  I won't spoil it here in case someone else decides they want to watch it and ends up liking it, but honestly, it was an awful plot. About 10 other sci-fi movies have done these individual concepts better. It felt a bit like the origin of the term "hack" for writers: someone took a dozen other, better films, chopped them to bits, and randomly stuck those bits back together to make this. When it's done well it ends up being a "mashup" or "x meets y", but in this case, "hack job" is what comes to mind.But - it's very pretty. Very visually atmospheric. Sadly, not good, but very pretty.
summary: Disliked this film, and not just because of Tom Cruise.

reviewText: I almost didn't buy this because I didn't want to buy the line, "it's got to be good because Tom cruise did this". But you know what, "Tom cruise only does A movies and he pours his soul into everything he does".  I'm glad I purchased this movie and in blu ray, it's worthy of the blu ray treatment and it merits being in my collection.PROS-Strong actors (I don't just mean Tom but, Morgan Freeman, Andrea Riseborough, Olga Kurylenko, Nikolaj Coster-Waldau, Memissa Leo -- they were all fantastic actors in this)-Strong characters-Storyline that keeps giving-Cool concept-It's got Tom cruise (I'm one of those people that don't want to like Tom just because every second of his real-life life is examined under a microscope and marketed to the ends of the world...in end I do like the actor....he's a talented hardworking actor and deserves the A listing)  This movie brought me back to respecting the actor.-Good character development (even the minor characters have a depth to them like Nikolaj Coster-Waldau who only gets a few minutes on camera but wow does he make the best of them! And Victoria, wow, she and Tom have to carry a good third of the movie alone and together so she does a tremendous job here -- best supporting comes to mind.)CONSNoneNo spoilers here.  You really have to watch the movie. The aliens invade, we push them back, Tom cruise is some kind of drone repair guy.Are there unanswered questions in the Movie?....yes most certainly but the movie is very good at helping you suspend disbelief with its strong visual portrayal, sound, strong acting.  To me two phrases are very important in sci fi: rational acting and plausible reality ---- Are the actors doing rational things in the movie?  YES (If you're ask yourself during a movie, "why did he do that? that's dumb! Then the actors are not acting rationally)- Is the story plausible?  YES (it's science fiction but yes it's plausible and yes you have to suspend disbelief just a bit)Some have compared this movie to Prometheus, a science fiction "mess of a movie" and it takes a lot for a guy like me to hang such a label on a movie....in Prometheus the actors are not doing rational things and the story is not really plausible (it makes no sense, the plot is not rational).  So it is categorically unfair to compare these two movies simply because both of their opening sequences are "pretty" in the visual sense.Oblivion's actors by contrast are strong rational, a tight story & plot that keeps giving (and the story is plausible), that is a huge difference --- couple that with Tom Cruise and the Cast's strong acting & beautiful filming and you have quite literally a masterpiece of science fiction.One final thing, some people critique that they figured it out pretty fast but I sincerely don't think the movie is meant to keep anything secret from the audience, a la sixth sense, I think it's a journey of discovery for Tom Cruise's character.  He's the one figuring things out.  We, the audience, are just along for the ride.
summary: It's Really Good - Yes, this is a Masterpiece

reviewText: Oblivion is a refreshing addition to the Sci-Fi realm. The story is fantastic and it's backed by a great cast. The premise involves an alien AI that poses as God, cloning and manipulating human beings in order to pillage planet earth for it's most abundant and valuable resource: water. As the plot unfolds, the protagonist--played by Tom Cruise (naturally)--struggles to make sense of his existence and win back the planet while protecting his long lost true love. I highly recommend this one for Sci-Fi fans.

reviewText: I'll make this short and sweet :- the similarities in plot devices and parallels between Oblivion and Moon (2009) struck me immediately. They are not identical, but their premises are oblique - which is not meant as criticism as much as its meant as comparison. Where one features a presumed man isolated on a mining base on the moon, the other posits a presumed man on earth following an alien invasion. Both have memories of people and situations in the past which they can't quite identify. Both come to confront replicas of their own physical beings. Both discover that they are androids. Both "sets" of androids die. Etc. Their are other, rather fundamental differences. Oblivion's Hans Zimmer-like score is maddening and distracting in the extreme. As usual, where this kind of thing is concerned, the minimalism in the music should not be the pounding, ostinato-driven repetition - but the MINIMAL use of music so as to ENHANCE its effect when its presence is required. When the score is nothing but another layer of unchanging sound, it ceases to be music and becomes noise -  it destroys, utterly, the purpose and real magic of music. Moon is much more recondite in its use of music. All this said, the best comparison of the two films would be by way of musical simile: where Moon is like chamber music (small in scope - restricted in range), Oblivion is operatic. Both are fine in their own ways - and, my objections to the score for Oblivion notwithstanding, both films work in their own, distinctive ways.

reviewText: I'm a (non-diehard) Sci-Fi fan, but have gotten extremely gun shy since there's so much bad Sci-Fi out there these days. I actually left this one in the player for about two weeks before I resigned myself to watching it - I shouldn't have waited so long!Some folks complain "the story was slow" - I think the operative word here is STORY (it actually has one)!It was refreshing to see a well made movie in which the special effects contribute / go hand in hand with the story, instead of simply trying to overwhelm you with what can be done with CGI, and overloading your senses in the process.BTW-his flying contraption was pretty darn cool!If you think it's slow, simply watch when you're in the mood for something "slow (er)".Personally, I didn't think it that slow (enough action and edge of the seat scenes), but if you're simply looking for an overloaded CGI smashfest, mebbe so?It also has a good soundtrack, which is always a bonus.

reviewText: I did not like this film. It was disorganized, very confusing, bad writing. One should not have to watch it more than once to try to uderstand it better. I really respect and enjoy these actors, Cruise, Freeman, but just not in this film. In this film they are tru heros with heart, but if I may, there was at least one segment where Freeman's character goes on a long speech like talk, solo, and all cast remain quiet as a mouse. I thought, this character is full of himself and likes hearing himself talk. It was similar to listening to him narrate a documentary. The producers should have cut that piece out to make him more likeable. The brunette actres, Olga, is so very pretty, her face and hair especially in this one, but she had very few words, it left me thinking perhaps she needs to work on her acting skills. In another film she played a silent warrior woman, I forget the title, it was pre middle ages timeline, she starred with Michael Fastbender, she nailed that role, great acting despite no words. She was good in that Bond film too. The plot in this Oblivion film to me was poorly done, too hard to follow, you had to work hard to understand, leaving you tired, with headache, wondering if this was a time and money waste to watch. In fact, on several occasions I often thought the film was about to end and it appeared to be winding down, and also it was dull, I think I was hoping it would end, it dragged on and on. If I knew what it was like, I would not have seen it even if for free. There was only one segment I liked, when Cruise was driving a small aircraft and was being chased by other craft, there was shooting between them, that was very exicting, but ended with an impossible scenario leaving me as a viewer insulted by the writers. The two main female characters were very easy on the eyes. Oh, and to top off the not so good on this film, was a silly female character with a southern accent which sounded very fake. She was somewhat of a manager role, wizard like, only seen on a tiny screen, calling the shots, but very unlikable, worse acting; again, if this film is very futuristic, it made you think, since in this film, earth is not the earth we once knew, then how in the world can one develop a southern accent if there is no such thing as the south; in fact, no East Coast community, no accents at all, because it is not the same USA or world for that matter. Someone else wrote, "there is an explanation for that 'female wizard TV monitor screen bossy character', I thought, there should not be an explanation, we should get it, the first time. However I agreed, there is probably and explanation for everything in this film, but why bother, I do not want to dream up or think or create a book a story in my head while I watch it, if I did I would be a writer, instead I thought i would see this film for entertainment, that did not happen. There seemed to have been segments cut which left you with more questions that answers. It gets worse, the film seems to go back and forth in time so often, there is even a double or twin of one character, how did that happen?; so you need to figure that out too. You need to figure this out, that out, etc. and so on and so on. Such so it leaves your headache feel like your brain is being blown apart into " oblivion." So at least they picked a perfect title. I am still stunned and I am ashamed to admit to anyone that I saw this movie. I think I need to keep this secret to myself. Buyer, beware. Be kind to yourself, do not see this film, or else you will regret it. One final scary thought, as I began to write this review, I saw some folks gave it high stars ratings, liking it. I cannot imagine how or why, that was scary to me. I thought this film was more bad sci fi, not at all horror. Signed... -- Not smart enough for this film.
summary: Very disappointed, let down, surprisingly bad

reviewText: What makes Oblivion stand out to me is that it doesn't really focus entirely on laser beams shooting everywhere and several elements of hard-to-follow suspense and excitement like you'd typically find in such science fiction movies that deal with the destruction/deterioration of planet Earth.  Instead these particular type of segments only occurs occasionally.  In its place lies segments involving drama concerning Tom Cruise's wife from 60 years prior found frozen in a capsule, and how she wakes up to find the world in its current state which is practically in ruins due to an alien invasion being the reason.  Tom Cruise of course is the man who's expected to save planet Earth!  Who else to play that role, right?While the occasional segments showing space crafts flying everywhere are certainly interesting and comparable to what you've seen countless times in similar science fiction movies, the storyline itself is rather confusing to figure out.  The doppelganger Tom Cruise that appears later on is when I finally got *completely* lost.  Also when Tom Cruise returns to his base and his current girlfriend (or wife- the redheaded chick) doesn't acknowledge the fight between her and Cruise that *just* took place a few minutes earlier apparently either because her memory went out or a change in time occurred without acknowledgement at some point.  Never could figure out which one truthfully.Morgan Freeman is a fantastic actor in his role as a deep-voiced leader, Olga Kurylenko is ridiculously cute as one would expect (but exceptionally cuter here!) and so is Andrea Riseborough.  Despite the confusing storyline and never knowing what's really happening on screen, one area where the movie truly exceeds is in the visuals.  Despite millions of people having been killed years earlier and the destruction of several famous structures and landmarks such as the Golden Gate Bridge, it all comes across appearing remarkably pretty and appealing oddly enough (especially the forest area that Tom would sometimes visit while listening to Led Zeppelin and Procol Harum, rock bands truly deserving of their classic status!)Overall, pretty awesome film, but expect to sit through a fair amount of drama and even romance which is more of a focus than anything else.
summary: not your ordinary science fiction film

reviewText: 2013 was a great year to be a science fiction movie fan. More than 10 sci fi films were released, all with great potential to be be top-notch.To be 100% honest, I didn't have high hopes for Oblivion if only because the other films looked so strong by comparison. Oblivion exceeded my expectations and then some.I won't go into the storyline as many other reviewers already have. I will say that yes, certain elements are derivitive. There are parts of Independence Day, The Matrix and other (rather good btw) sci fi stories in the plot of Oblivion. However, at no point did I feel that any other film was being "ripped-off". Oblivion has enough of it's own original ideas and variation of classic themes to make it stand on it's own. New and old ideas both come together and make a rather satisfying film.Tom Cruise is solid here as is Morgan Freeman (is he ever in a bad movie?). The rest of the cast - especially Andrea Riseborough - are both believable and relatable. I especially enjoyed Melissa Leo as "Sally". Definitely an interesting take on the character she portrays.Lastly, both the special effects and score were great - both added quite a lot to the film.I've watched it numerous times and highly recommend it.
summary: More than the sum of it's parts...

reviewText: If you're looking for an okay sci-fi post-apocalyptic movie to watch, you could do worse than Oblivion. You could do a lot better too. It's the future and astronaut Jack Harper (Cruise) is running around doing work fixing machines on a destroyed planet Earth. Earth is all messed up because aliens blew up the moon 60 years ago. The movie has some great visuals and, while there is a lot of predictability, there's enough to keep you guessing and engaged in the movie. They did a good job keeping it only 2 hours long. No need to stretch it out, just present a good popcorn flick.The only things that really bugged me about Oblivion were the Matrix rip-offs. Yes, a man vs. machine sci-fi film is going to draw those comparisons, but the droids in Oblivion are ridiculously similar to the sentinels in The Matrix, and I expected to see Neo show up in one of the final scenes of the movie ("Whoa!").In a lot of ways Oblivion also reminded me of the movie "Moon" with Sam Rockwell. Kind of ironic that they blew up the moon in this and the entire story of THAT film takes place on the moon. "Moon" is FAR superior to Oblivion. Less action and CGI, more suspense and drama. If you liked Oblivion, you'll love Moon. If you didn't like Oblivion or only thought it was so-so, you'll enjoy Moon more. And you won't leave that one thinking you've just seen an elaborate Verison "Droid" commercial!

reviewText: Everything in this movie is perfect. The music is amazing, the actors are perfect for their roles, the storyline is astonishing and surprising, and the movie itself is so visually stunning.In the year 2077, aliens attacked earth. They were defeated, but earth was completely destroyed. Rome, London, New York City; all lie beneath hundreds of feet of sand and rubble. The TET is collecting survivors for transport to one of Saturn's moons, Titan. Jack and Vicka remain below, handling logistics and repairing drones and hydro-reactors that are converting the earth's oceans into energy for the colony in Titan.That's all I can tell you; you have to watch the movie. It is so incredibly well put together. The storyline holds you in suspense and mystery for a very long time, and the climactic scene is simply epic. I cannot compliment this movie enough.However, the ending is a bit disappointing, so just stop the movie about 2 minutes before then.This is a must watch, a true epic, and possibly one of the best movies of 2013.

reviewText: After watching the TV trailers for this film, I had absolutely no interest in it. They emphasized the scene in the library which made this movie look just like any of dozens of pseudo sci-fi "fight the monsters in the dark" films. I've enjoyed some films of that type but after 30+ years they've worn thin by now.Just for the heck of it, my wife and I just watched this on streaming video and found a VERY different film than expected. With a few action scenes worked in here and there, this is actually a very thoughtful and surprising post-apocalyptic sci-fi story.Set about 70 years in the future, the Earth has reportedly won a war with alien invaders by resorting to the nuclear option. The relatively few people left have abandoned Earth to live on Titan (a large moon of Jupiter), and the few people left hanging around are protecting large machines that are generating needed power for the colony by sucking up the Earth's oceans.Tom Cruise plays Jack, one of these survivors whose job is to repair weaponized drones which protect the power generating machines. Along with a female partner, they spend their nights in a luxurious base and their days working to find and repair drones downed by the remnants of the invading army.The surprises in this film won't be shocking for highly experienced sci-fi fans, but their gradual revelation makes for a very intriguing and very thoughtful story. Jack's increasing self-awareness and his struggle to arrive at the truth is a fascinating story which is 180 degrees different than the movie suggested by the ads ... and trust me that's a GOOD thing! :-)Well, any more than this and I'd be getting to spoiler territory ... as if there likely aren't hundreds of reviews with spoilers out there anyway. LOL I'll just say that we found this to be an excellent film with plot twists that kept us guessing for quite some time. Cruise leads a cast full of the excellent acting performances that drive this first rate plot.The special effects are clean and convincing. The HD streaming version looks great, although the dialogue at times seems to be a bit low compared to the surrounding ambient noise and audio effects.Highly recommended.
summary: Wow, was this advertised with the wrong emphasis

reviewText: (NOTE for anyone who wants to give a negative review: please leave a comment to help me do better next time.)First: DO NOT READ Amazon's description of OBLIVION!  It gives away key PLOT SPOILERS.For my part, I will quite deliberately tell you only a little about the plot, as I think it really is best kept as a surprise. Thankfully, the commercials do not do it an injustice, and will not spoil your viewing.The merest details of the story are as follows: Jack Harper (Cruise) is a repairman known as Tech 49 whose assignment is providing security in order to keep Hydrorig machinery running on what's left of our planet after a ravaging horde of aliens destroyed almost our entire race six decades ago.  Alien scavengers are sabotaging the rigs on a daily basis, and all Jack and his partner are hoping for is to finish their job and join the remainder of Earth's survivors on Titan, a moon of Saturn.As for anything else, it's best you keep your mind clear until you see the movie.The acting is very competent and while not entirely engaging, it doesn't have to be: the movie aims for a deliberate aloofness here. And, though the movie has Cruise in almost every shot it is not a typical star turn for him.  For once Cruise has selected a movie that features him but is not ABOUT him, in a sense...it's about what secret lies behind their strange day-to-day existences.Olga Kurylenko (Quantum of Solace) and Andrea Riseborough (Brighton Rock) are excellent, as is Melissa Leo (Flight,Olympus Has Fallen).  While Morgan Freeman is featured prominently in the ads, he does not play a large role in the film...though it is pivotal.OBLIVION is an interesting mix...lots of action, yet it tries to be a thinker. As such, it does provide a puzzle that needs to be put together by the viewer. The real, ultimate problem is that once that's accomplished there isn't a lot there to ponder afterward.  There's a twist, yes; it just isn't all that intellectual. ThinkPlanet Of The Apes (1968)without the BIG shock.What OBLIVION does really well is look good. It superimposes post-apocalytic scenes of desecrated New York landmarks upon a desolate landscape laid waste by enemy invaders. Shot in Iceland during their 24-hour cycles of daylight, the juxtaposition makes for a stark composition of collapse and ruination...an earth no longer even worth inhabiting.As always, the desolation is New York City's: the Manhattan (or is it Brooklyn?) Bridge juts out of the silt, in the midst of a rocky crag there is an entrance to a big interior room of the New York Public Library, the Empire State Building appears only from the observation tower on up, and a big football stadium (is it the Met Life Stadium?) lies in ruins.What director Joseph Kosinski (Tron: Legacy) and cinematographer Claudio Miranda (Life Of Pi) accomplish is to produce the devastation of Earth through the browns, blacks, and greys of the soil and rocks, counterpointed by the bright blueness of the ever-present sky. There is a gorgeous iridescent blue and black night swimming scene in Jack's sky suite, wherein the two actors swim tastefully naked inside a transparent pool. Indeed, Cruise's silver-blue uniform and his clear glass bubble-like helicopter are sleek and artistically interposed in this world of greys, blues and browns. When they travel into space, it is primarily dark and black. When he is trapped within the hidden caverns of his enemy it is a dark, shadowy world of blacks, greys, and browns.There is only one place in this whole movie that really displays color, and it is a hideaway Jack  has created for himself in what one can only assume is New York's Adirondacks -- though these scenes were shot in California. It's a little hamlet of lush greenery that has within it a cabin of artifacts Jack's lifted upon his trips around the ruins of NYC. He has tucked away books, Procul Harum and Led Zeppelin albums, a doll, and photos near and dear to him. The audience at my showing had a little chuckle at the fact that he places on one shelf his own iconic sunglasses...to my way of thinking, the trademark of one Mr. "Top Gun" Cruise.So the film is strikingly visual, and a beauty to see at the theater. I saw it in an IMAX theater (though it was not shot that way) and it was gorgeous. Besides that, the soundtrack by French band M83 is also alternately pensive and rousing, peacefully employing a lone piano one moment, then next dishing up an insistent orchestral piece.All in all, OBLIVION is a beautiful, striking, thoughtful work, though it doesn't -- as perennial one-year old genius Stewie Griffin might say -- "leave us richer for the experience."
summary: Visually Arresting, But Not Quite the Thinker It Hopes To Be

reviewText: "Good" - the special effects, including their skybase and the jetcopter, were visually stunning (which is expected from Hollywood)."Bad" - the props and the thin plot. Tom Cruise' uniform and his rifle are cheap and phony to the point of distraction. The uniform Tom Cruise wears is right out of The Day the Earth Stood Still.... the 1950's version, and the rifle is obviously light plastic as he throws it around like a wiffle ball bat.By design, the setting was one of isolation and loneliness, unfortunately this was combined with a thin, uninspired plot which exacerbated the movie's weaknesses. The visuals were striking, but once I adjusted to this I was looking for more substance and plot, which were only partially delivered. Under the circumstances, a deeper, more intriguing plot was necessary.The pace picked up somewhat near the end, with some nice twists, but even these were recognizable themes that leave you with the sense of "I've seen this stuff before". This movie needed more Morgan Freeman and little less Tom Cruise.It is not a bad movie. I enjoyed it...somewhat, but it never grabbed me. I was initially amazed by the visuals, but as this wore off, I was left with mild indifference to the simple storyline. I've been on a multi-year rant about Hollywood blockbusters that spend countless millions on special effects and big name actors, but apparently spend very little on writing, and in my opinion this is another example of my gripe. This blockbuster movie that could have and should have been much better with relatively little effort.

reviewText: There is a little something here for everyone. If your idea of Science Fiction is technology and CGI firefights this movie has it. If you want a hero with heart, as much as I don't like Tom Cruise's real persona, he delivers. If you are tired of psychological manipulation and lies, the plot celebrates the value of truth over a many layered deception. If you hate drones and the idea of mindless mechanized destruction you'll love it. If you love the Earth and believe in the triumph of love and the human spirit you will be uplifted (for a change). Tired of Zombies, senseless violence, and seeing the worst humanity has to offer? This is your film. Held my interest right to the end and that hasn't happened in a long long time.
summary: A Beautiful Balance that Celebrates Humanity

reviewText: I really enjoyed this movie because of the novel plot. Not overly done action or drama was a plus. The underlying message/ story line is unparallelled. Spoiler - This turned out to be a tale of one man and two wives. One was not a real wife and wanted to live in a small artificial and isolated world, the truth pushed out, where she hovered over her man, only allowing him the occasional escape to his man cave...cabin in the woods. With her as a partner, he was less than he was...more boy than man. Second wife was a true wife that he could bring into his man world and though not controlling, he was at his greatest with her in his world. He was man/hero in that world. She readily became part of his world and even after he was gone she remained there.

reviewText: Oblivion2013124 minAction/Adventure/Sci-FiApril 19, 2013USADirector:Joseph KosinskiWriters:Karl Gajdusek - screenplay, Michael Arndt - screenplayStars:Tom Cruise, Morgan Freeman, and Olga KurylenkoUnderrated SciFi as far as I am concerned.  Some critics may say there are parallels and similarities to other movies, but I didn't feel that and I have seen most the SciFi movies out there from the last sixty years.  Whether you are a fan of Cruise or Morgan or not, it doesn't matter.  The story is compelling enough to satisfy most SciFi fans.  I went into this with no more than a few glimpses of preview scenes and no idea of the ending at all.  Although had I known it would have detracted some from the experience, it still wouldn't take away from the overall story, acting, scenery, and special effects.  My step-daughter begged me to pause it whenever she left the room, and my wife was upset when she came downstairs and realized we were watching it without her.  I had bought this so my wife need not worry about viewing it, but my point is the ladies will enjoy this one too so be sure they are present.A man and woman are left to finish mining the oceans before joining the rest of mankind on Jupiter's moon Titan.  They have both had memory wipes but the man is seeing flashbacks of another time.  He starts to question who he really is and does he really want to leave Earth.  What he finds out while fighting the alien scavengers will change mankind forever.Recommendations:Planet Of The Apes,The Time Machine, andMinority ReportCA Luster

reviewText: I was expecting what passes for a typical, modern, post-apocalyptic, big-budget sci-fi movie with Oblivion: a movie that was more suited to a bargain bin, just a hair above a 'b' sci-fi channel flick; and maybe not even that.  Loaded with trite messages about how bad humans are or how we screwed up the planet or some other tired overdone plot with all the distracting special effects the creators could junk into the frame at a time.  Instead I found myself really enjoying this movie.  It had very well done special effects that felt real and added to the story instead of becoming the focal point themselves.  The actors did a decent job, and the plot was familiar yet had some unique elements that kept it very entertaining and even gave it re-watch-ability.  I think it has wide appeal, especially to lovers of the genera.

reviewText: The art direction, graphics, and soundtrack alone make this a really nice experience. I was impressed with the careful attention paid to every detail in this film and found the art direction and soundtrack to be exceptional.  There has been criticism of the film that it is highly derivative of a broad range of science fiction action films of the recent past but I found it entertaining and suspenseful. There was a consistency of vision in the film that must reflect what director Joseph Kosinski wished to achieve.Tom Cruise proves once again that he can give a highly convincing performance as the leading man in a futuristic film. This future is bleak since earth is now a resource for a mysterious machine driven power that is sucking earth dry. Like many films and stories, Jack, the character played by Cruise, undergoes an awakening of consciousness regarding the power or authority under which he works. He discovers much about the rag-tag cave survivors on earth and in a play with time finds a capsule with a beautiful women inside.  The viewer makes sense of it all at the same time that the truth begins to unfold for Jack, a time honored technique in story-telling. Jack has had his memory erased and thus as he makes sense of the world in which he lives, so does the viewer of the film.This is a good looking movie with some of the best art direction I have seen in a while. I loved the soundtrack, it was perfect for the look and feel of this film.
summary: Visually stunning film with great soundtrack

reviewText: This movie is 'high' Sci-Fi, as opposed to 'low' Sci-Fi.  What this means is this :  It's meant to provoke you to think and ponder the prospects of the story's scenario.  Therefore, it's a GREAT Sci-Fi for true Sci-Fi fans, whereas, it may not be well suited for someone whose expecting your normal Tom Cruise type action movie.  Though it has really good action, it's more a Sci-Fi drama than an action movie.  The effects and production value are TOP NOTCH.  The director was very good, as was the acting.The movie kind of leaves you hanging with all sorts of unanswered questions, and, for me at least, this is not a bad thing.  I was left wanting to know more about what happened before the movie's time frame, as well as after.  In fact, I'd bet that if they did a part 2 based on what occurred BEFORE the movie's time-frame, it'd be great to see !The robotic sentries in the movie actually stole a few scenes they were in...they were truly well depicted, and, for the first time an any film I've seen, a robotic presence actually felt scary...scary because incredibly capable, tough, and ruthless.Don't hesitate to see this movie.  Cruise does a great job, and his character ends up being quite complex and human.  The effects are beautiful to behold.  In fact, this movie is a pleasure to behold because the lighting and effects are at times staggeringly beautiful.  No cheese in this movie.  No filler either.  I only wish it could have covered a bit more terrain in relation to its core conception of story and related events.  But I'm not complaining.
summary: Stimulating Sci-Fi.  A thinking man's movie.  Beautifully shot.

reviewText: I would have given this a higher rating, but can't give half stars. Tom Cruise proves that he can still make a good movie, despite all the 'baggage'. I did find myself thinking about that during the movie, which was distracting. This was a good movie, nonetheless.Additional details:Tom Cruise plays Jack Harper, a drone maintenance technician in some future where mankind has had a war with an alien race. A war which has left the Earth mostly uninhabitable. A few technicians and their controllers remain on Earth to repair and maintain the automated drones that protect harvesters which create energy from seawater. The remaining humans are living either in the TET, a massive space station in orbit, or are orbiting Titan, a moon of Saturn. Once their tour is over, Tom and his controller, Victoria, are to transfer to the TET and then go to Titan. You see early on that Jack is dissatisfied with leaving the Earth, and finds beauty in small things, such as a flower growing in the midst of a massive desert. You also see that Victoria is a `ask no questions and do your job' personality. As the film progresses, this difference between the two characters becomes more and more evident. I don't want to spoil anything about the remainder of the movie's plot, so I'll leave it there.The special effects in this movie are some of the best that I've ever seen, and the flight sequences of the `bubble ship' that cruise uses to go out to repair the drones, are awesome. I really enjoyed the behind the scenes footage that is included. The version that I purchased included the DVD, Blu-Ray, digital copy, and Vudu streamed version of the film, so having the proper player was no issue at all.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yes, here is yet ANOTHER "apocalyptic flick" in a long list of other apocalyptic themed movies this year.This movie is strange.  Set in 2077, on a "war ravaged earth", our hero Tom Cruise (Jack) and his partner Vicka have the important job of harvesting water and other ecological necessities for human's new place of residence, Titan.Jack is the one who has to do the "dirty work" - going down to the ground to battle the "Scavs" that have taken over earth.  (The scavs are the aliens that waged the war on humans to begin with)...while Vicka, on the other hand (a woman who is way too neat and sexily dressed to really be believable in this type scenario, but oh well...) never leaves the tall luxurious tower they are stationed in.Yes, they are romantically involved.Is this movie interesting?  Yes, in it's own way.  It is certainly VISUALLY interesting, and Tom Cruise does a great job as the main character.  (Some men may find Vicka visually interesting, as well).But is it INTERESTING?????  Well....sort of.  I mean, the movie does suck you in and holds your interest - although I did feel, at times, that there could have been "more" - more character development, more emotion...just "MORE".  However, I do feel the movie is worth watching ONCE....now would I watch it again?  Since I know all the little secrets and interesting twists (which I will not divulge) I can't see myself watching the flick again, any time soon.  It did seem to drag a bit in places too, unfortunately.Over all, though, I would recommend seeing Oblivion at least once.  It's worth it.  Perhaps watch in on Pay Per View as opposed to purchasing.

reviewText: "Oblivion" is a true science fiction story. I say that because a true science fiction story has technology, gadgets and a futuristic view of the world. Of course in "Oblivion" the future of earth is destined for nuclear catastrophe and that theme has been done so many times in movies, it must be true. There are new kinds of drones that are not small planes that drop bombs on targets, but large "Robocop" like circular machines with turrets and a programmed mind that annihilates most anything that moves. Finally, we have a spectacularly cool plane that twists and turns and truly must be seen to explain.The biggest thing standing in the way of "Oblivion", in my opinion, is an advertisement that claims that it is the best film of the year. Well, it is only April and the summer blockbuster season and the end of the year Oscar season haven't even arrived yet, but that's a pretty bold statement. So, is it?I want to say that "Oblivion" is one of the most creative science fiction movies I've seen in years, but I'm going to hold off on that because truly, its creativity is a collage of many science fiction movies that came before it. I'm not going to list those movies because I don't want to give anything away, but there are probably six. Tom Cruise plays Jack Harper, a mechanic assigned to a wife who work as a team patrolling an area that wasn't affected by nuclear fallout and repairing downed drones. Harper and all other known survivors have had their memories cleared; yet he continues to have dreams of his past life."Oblivion" has a moody pace to it, occasionally it is eventful and consuming and occasionally it is slow and dramatic. Unlike many movies these days that spend zero time at all building up character and just want to dazzle you with all the really nifty effects they've discovered, "Oblivion" does the opposite; it puts character first and then sucks you in with the effects. Maybe a happy medium would have worked better, but I'm not going to complain because I'm tired of movies that make you feel nothing but, "Wow! That looked cool." Thankfully, somebody in Hollywood realizes that you need to put heart first when telling a story. If you're tired of emotion-free action/science fiction movies as well, you'll probably love "Oblivion".I have a hard time believing by the end of 2013 that "Oblivion" will be the best movie of the year. The elements that make up the story are way too recycled to have too much of an impact down the road. Although for now, the realizations of the technology and the heart that it delivers make it the best movie I've seen so far this year. Thankfully, great actors like Morgan Freeman, Tom Cruise, Olga Kurylenko and an emotional performance by Andrea Risenborough turned a stale story into something memorable and good.
summary: Moody, but has heart where others rely on relentless explosions
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was a nice relief from what currently masquerades as Sci Fi these days. Great story, thin characters that allowed the story to shine thru and CGI that added to the story, rather than taking over from it.I mention the CGI because when CGI is done right, it makes you want to have the device, be in the story and believe in the future tech. Too many movies these days have a story that falls flat on it's face, Then tries to make up for that with CGI.Oblivion is CGI done just right, adding to this complex, but yet simply told story that will never fail to surprise you too. Watching it for the second time tonight!From a writer's point of view, this is the retelling of the Moses story. When you watch this. look for the shapes that we know well from Egypt, the idea of Moses stopping the abuse of a slave by an over-seer and some other images that will tell you more. Won't spoil this for you, but there is more than meets the eye, in Oblivion's imagery.
summary: Great Movie - Nice Straight Forward Sci Fi

reviewText: Tom Cruise is awesome playing a "repairman" for robotic drones that patrol the earth to kill "invaders" who seem to be intent on sabotaging Cruise's efforts to maintain the drones and also want to destroy the massive devices which are sucking up all the waters of the oceans on earth.  All this while Cruise and his "companion" live in a luxury "condo in the sky" which includes a transparent swimming pool.  SPOILER ALERT:  Cruise is all gungho with his responsibilities, but seems to be finding things that "distract" him from his usual duties AND he encounters little clues that raise his curiosity contrary to the wishes of his companion.  This escalates when he encounters a crashed spaceship and manages to find a survivor... a beautiful female.  He has been experiencing fragmented "dreams" and it turns out the survivor is the woman in his dreams and events escalate thereafter... reviewText: I might as well admit I went to see this because I wanted to see what it felt like to purchase a ticket to oblivion.  The story, as far as I can tell, is one where the hero is either awake, dreaming, dreaming he's awake or dreaming he's dreaming.  Not exactly Total Recall, but if you think they ran Blade Runner through the office copier for Total Recall, Oblivion borrows from everything from Planet of the Apes to Aeon Flux.  One thing these mega movies teach us is that money does not buy originality.In the end, I think it's the effects and visual design that make Oblivion entertaining.  You know there's trouble when Morgan Freeman has to fill you in on what's up with the story around the 90 minute mark.  Anyhow, my take on the story.  There has been a war.  The earth was victorious but the planet was left uninhabitable except for a little spread that Tom owns, but that comes later.  Since nobody can live on earth, security is handled by a crew of just 2 people; Tom and a gal who looks like Kate Winslet on a crash diet.  They live in a 50's modern glass house on top of a microwave antenna.  The house has a pool that's like a Corningware baking dish, but larger.One day, Tom falls through the ceiling of the reading room in the New York Public Library.  He looks for books by L. Ron Hubbard, but the place is a mess and all he can find is a book about dying with honor and purpose.  Then, his wife shows up, which creates a little friction at home, so Tom starts staying out late in his spaceship even though things on earth are dangerous after dark.In the end, Tom discovers the whole setup is a hoax, run by the folks in the big space station overhead.  You can guess the rest but I won't tell you, except to say he goes up to the big space HQ and it's filled with humans who are in cold storage.  In one of Oblivion's few innovations, these folks are stored sitting down which, I'm sorry to say made it look like each was on the toilet.  End of world but with clean restrooms, I guess.  BTW, I forgot to mention Tom also discovers that he is somebody else, somebody else is him and they fight over it.Whatever Oblivion was about, I liked it for the effects and soundtrack.  So long as you don't get hung up trying to figure out the story, I recommend it.

reviewText: In "Oblivion," Tom Cruise plays a repair tech named Jack Harper who travels an abandoned Earth in the year 2077 fixing robot drones. A war broke out years ago with the nomadic Scavs, the only threat still roaming the planet. While the Scavs lost the war, they destroyed the moon and made Earth uninhabitable. Now Jack and his assigned team mate Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) are the only two people left while the rest of the population relaxes comfortably on Titan located on Saturn's moon. Despite a mandatory memory wipe for everyone on the planet, Jack still dreams of a woman that isn't Victoria. He begins to question his mission when a spaceship known as The Odyssey crash lands near Jack while he's out on a run and the woman from his dreams literally falls into his lap.The only other film Joseph Kosinski has directed is "TRON: Legacy," so does that mean the soundtrack has to sound exactly the same? To be clear, the soundtrack isn't bad but you kind of write it off because it sounds so similar to Daft Punk's soundtrack of Kosinski's previous film. The one main difference is that there is a ton of synthesizer near the end of "Oblivion," so much that you can actually picture an astronaut on the moon playing a keyboard guitar during the slower moments of the film.That sense of familiarity seriously plagues "Oblivion" because it will remind you of at least half a dozen different movies during its just over two hour duration. Tom Cruise seems to intentionally make nods to "Top Gun" while flying his futuristic dragonfly-shaped helicopter thing. He even pulls out a pair of aviator sunglasses and places them on a shelf in this delicate "remember this?" kind of manner. "Oblivion" seems to make the mistake of having an expected sci-fi plot point in its loins without much of anything else to back it up. To get there, it piggybacks on the likes of "I Am Legend," "The Matrix," "Independence Day," and "Moon." The issue is it feels like it doesn't try hard enough to leave a big enough impact to actually be remembered by the end of the year let alone six months from now. "Oblivion" is like a clone of a clone of a good sci-fi film.Tom Cruise spends a lot of time flying around, sticking his fingers deep into the innards of broken robots, and turning them on. All you'd need is for him to whisper dirty things to them while his fist is still inside them and you'd have some futuristic porno on your hands. "Oblivion" is absolutely breathtaking to watch. Earth may be deserted, but it's still beautiful in this empty kind of way. The lush landscapes are incredible. Pretty much anything involving the drones is a lot of fun. In a way, "Oblivion" is a lot like "Mission: Impossible - Ghost Protocol" since the futuristic technology is really creative and just a blast for the audience in general. The drones make so many beeps and boops that you know somewhere R2D2 is getting a stiffy. If you have an inner sci-fi nerd, the intense visuals and electronic sounds of the film may give you the same reaction. There's a drone chase sequence near the end of the film that is pretty outstanding.But somehow everything else going on is really dull. Tom Cruise is torn between two beautiful women? How tragic! Morgan Freeman shows up long enough to do his best Morpheus impression and smoke a cigar in the dark. You can see where the film is going to go, but poor Jack takes an extra 45 minutes to get there because he's got to figure out who this other woman is (which you can figure out the second or third time he dreams about her). Most importantly you won't care where the film is going to go. You can see the big finale coming once Jack returns to that cabin for the second time. The story being told is just so dry and stale. Imagine clipping coupons with a lightsaber or using warp speed on the Star Trek Enterprise to get to the laundromat to fold clothes and stretch either of those tasks out for two hours and you have "Oblivion.""Oblivion" is visual science fiction ecstasy yet is so structurally boring that you'll be edging towards the door two thirds of the way through the film. It attempts to mold this futuristic adventure out of borrowed concepts and mimicked ideas from similar genre films, but it does not compute. It is not an effective team.
