reviewText: I remain among the minority that still think that Tom Cruise is a fantastic leading man.  I have pondered about his films he has made over the last few years, and there is actually a decent lineup.  I adored Knight and Day and Mission Impossible: Ghost Protocol is a masterful piece of work.  Also, I will watch War of the Worlds any day of the week!  Cruise is so charismatic that I can't do anything BUT enjoy his performances.  Do I disagree with his religious views, among other things?  Yes.  But, if we, the viewing public, were to boycott films that star people that we disagree with, we would end up not seeing any movies.  As a minority among critics (I'm a conservative Mormon), I would have to limit myself to Michael Bay movies.  So, I think that when considering any form of art, we shouldn't discriminate based on the artist's beliefs unless they are forcing them down our throats.Oblivion is directed by Joe Kosinki, the director of a little known film called Tron: Legacy.  I adored said film, and was determined to look past the early negative reviews of his new venture because of my love of Tron.  Ultimately, the only prep that one should have going into this film is that it is a love letter to the sci-fi genre and in particular to that genre's best films.  People are complaining about this and the plethora of plot twists.  Neither bothered me.THE BADThe first act and much of the second drags.  I actually blame this on the trailers: I've seen the film's many trailers many times and it gives away the revelation that happens in the first act.  Also, the trailer was deceptive in giving false impressions of how the mood of the film would be.  It was REALLY different than I was led to believe it would be.THE GOODThe plot twists are fantastic.  I really felt that the actual reveals were subtle enough to evoke real emotion and allow the audience empathize with every one of the characters.  I compare the twists to the ones in The Village in that all the problems that many of the character and verisimilitude issues that I thought were present in the first hour were explained and actually well done.The music is really quite good.  It feels like it could have been by Daft Punk and has a similar feel to Tron: Legacy.  I wish that the trailer that we as regular movie-goers were bombarded with had included this because I think it would have been a good selling point.Morgan Freeman phones in his performance, but even his phoned-in performances are spectacular!  Also, I feel like Cruise gave a great performance.It seems that every review that I read mentioned how beautiful the film looks, and they weren't kidding.  The special effects are breathtaking.  The lighting is really good too.  Also, the sound effects (a trivial thing, I know) were well above average.  I wouldn't be surprised if this film takes the Oscar for sound editing.CONCLUSIONI started out not caring for this film, but as the plot progressed and I reveled in the reveals, I found myself to be really satisfied.  It's still not one I will own, but it's worth seeing.  4/5 Stars.PARENTS GUIDEThis has a pretty intense sex scene for a PG-13.  It has sexual nudity.  Also, it's pretty violent.  NOT FOR CHILDREN.  The sex scene is pretty pointless.
summary: Fun the first viewing, but not worth owning

reviewText: In his follow-up effort to 2010's Tron: Legacy, Joseph Kosinski brings us Oblivion, a visually striking and futuristic sci-fi epic that boasts a strong performance from Tom Cruise and an intriguing, albeit recycled, story.In 2017, Earth is transformed and deemed inhospitable due to an invasion by an alien race nicknamed the Scavs. Sixty years after this event, the human race has abandoned the planet for the Saturn moon of Titan. Only two humans remain, Jack (played by Tom Cruise), a security repairman who is tasked with fixing security drones, and Victoria (played by Andrea Riseborough), Jack's communications officer and partner. Due to join their fellow compatriots on the enormous space station known as the TET in two weeks, a vessel crash-lands on Earth and causes Jack to question everything he knows about the people he trusts, his mission, and ultimately himself.The biggest achievement of the film belongs to Kasinski, who's vision and direction make this film an absolute wonder to behold. Much like Tron: Legacy, Oblivion contains breathtaking landscapes and dazzling futuristic designs. The look and feel of decimated Earth is truly spectacular and oddly realistic. It's an amazing achievement in visual effects, and it's for this reason alone that seeing the film is worth it.Another impressive factor of the movie is the cast, which is quite small. Jack and Victoria get the bulk of the screen time as the first half of the film is devoted almost entirely to them. Luckily, Cruise and Riseborough have a great chemistry and pull of the "last two people on Earth" thing quite nicely. Cruise continues to prove age has not diminished his action-star status and he's particularly good here. The film is more character-driven than the previews would have you believe so having a versatile and well-known actor in the lead spot is a definite plus. A lot of credit also has to be given to Riseborough who is absolutely brilliant in her role as the content worker bee who doesn't want to see the facts laid out in front of her.The one caveat most people seem to have with the movie is that it heavily borrows ideas from many other sci-fi flicks, including Moon, the Matrix, Total Recall, and Eagle Eye to name a few. I find this kind of silly because most sci-fi films borrow from each other in some way or another and while most of Oblivion's ideas may not be entirely original, the execution and visuals more than make up for this. It's an inventive and strikingly beautiful sci-fi epic that holds it's own when it comes to character development and overall story. If you're a fan of sci-fi (or any of the above-mentioned films) definitely check this out.

reviewText: There exists an ache deep within each of us, longing to know who we are, where we came from, and why we were created. Deep down in the core of our being, we know there is something more. Like Jack Harper, we do not want to simply live a purposeless life as the security repair man; a sterile life of a thousand repetitions.In this sense, Jack typifies all of humanity in this movie. In him, we find the war waging within each of us. Do we allow ourselves to forget who we are? Do we give in to sin, and allow it to dull our intellect, even our memory? How many of us have lost our joy, our vigor for life. How far we have fallen indeed, and how sad and cynical we have become. Earth really *is* devastated. Yet there is still hope for humanity, in compassion, in love. In this way, Jack serves as a figure of all humanity, who's self-revelation marks a new beginning for mankind.

reviewText: I'm a big sci-fi fan. I have been kind of off Tom Cruise after he managed open his mouth and stick his foot in his mouth so many times.. When I saw the previews of the movie they looked good and I was encouraged that Morgan Freeman also starred in this movie.When I saw the movie, it was very well written. It had a small cast, but each of the primary characters were very well done by the actors. This movie had great special effects. I liked how the set was both futuristic but also demonstrated all of the destruction on the planet. I also really enjoyed how the screenplay slowly revealed what was really going on, despite the way things seemed. That was quite a twist in the storyline.There were quite a few things on the set of this movie that took real vision to set just the right atmosphere necessary for this movie. Kudos.I enjoyed this movie so much that I had to add it to my collection. I was thrilled when I found the Blu-ray, dvd and digital copy edition on sale just before Christmas. I have really developed a preference for buying movies that have a digital copy available whenever it's possible. Now I can even watch this movie and enjoy it with a collection of other digital movies on my pc.I really enjoyed this movie. I recommend this movie to other sci-fi fans. I hope you enjoy it as well.

reviewText: Actually, Tom Cruise has come back to Earth (in real life) and his being cast in a Sci-Fi movie occurring right here on earth is quite appropriate. But I love a good Sci-Fi movie and this one is pretty good. It evokes emotions like 2001 Space Odyssey. Beautiful. You don't like the acting? What are you comparing it to? Its Tom Cruise. Hey, he does all his own stunts, convincingly. He's no J. Nicholson or A. Hopkins but he's not a bad actor. I'm glad he's come back to reality (again, in real life). You think there is too much CGI? Too Digital? Again, what are you comparing it to? Are you sure you knew you were watching a Sci-Fi movie? Actually if you watch the "Making of" on the blu-ray it explains there is a lot more "reality" in the movie than you might think and less CGI. But its a modern science fiction movie. CGI is required to tell the story, but I think this movie is a perfect balance. The drones are the coolest, even though they are villains. I love the noises they make... kind of like R2-D2 on steroids. The score is fantastic. You can watch the movie with only the score playing. That's a little weird, but the score can probably stand on its own if you are into just listening to a movie soundtrack by itself. One question I have about one of the characters, Vika, is why are her eyes so dilated all the time? It is spooky looking. Why I am writing a review of this movie that hundreds of people have already given their dumb opinions of, I don't know. Just thought I would offer mine because I liked it so much. Besides the movie, the "making of" is a very interesting documentary. Its in 5 parts and in HD as well. Its almost as good as the movie itself. I own the blu-ray and the video is of outstanding quality. Can't comment on the audio since I have not watched it with surround.

reviewText: I saw this movie last week in the theater and I liked it (hence the 4 star rating).  I'm not a big movie snob so every movie doesn't have to be an Oscar contender for me.  I'm just looking for a fun time at the movies so I usually go into a movie like this hoping for some good action and some cool visual effects.Oblivion does not disappoint when it comes to the great visuals.  Overall, the story was pretty good.  Some of it was predictable and I am usually pretty good at predicting what is going to happen next, but I honestly was pleasantly surprised at a few of the twists in the movie.  I saw it coming, but not in the way that I expected.  With this movie, you get some pretty cool future tech vehicles and weapons and some good action.  Overall, the story was a little confusing at first, but was pretty clearly explained in a few short flashbacks, which doesn't leave you going "huh?" at the end of the movie.In conclusion, Oblivion is one of those movies that I'm glad I saw.  I'm not sure that I need to see it again, so I'm on the fence about buying it.  It is a pretty typical Sci-Fi movie.  If you go in just looking for a decent Sci-Fi flick, you probably won't be disappointed with this one.  It looks great in the theater, so that would probably be your best if you can make it out.  Otherwise, it is definitely worth a rental, and possibly a purchase.
summary: A Movie Review from Just a Normal Dude!

reviewText: Tom Cruise plays the last man on Earth, a high-tech janitor of sorts who's left to mind the planet's robotic chaperones while the rest of the species lives it up on one of Saturn's moons. It's slow, predictable and riddled with holes, but the production's cache of slick, attractive future tech and constant visual revelations make for excellent diversions. Cruise's sleekly designed equipment is a real science fiction goldmine, visionary in the same sense as Minority Report's giant touch-screen UIs, and the first hour is an outstanding lesson in world-building. The plot eventually falls into too many Cruise / mainstream Hollywood pitfalls, though, and borrows too liberally from other films. Duncan Jones's excellent Moon, in particular, is robbed of all but its subtlety, performances and locale. Still, such faults are hardly surprising by this point and if you were anticipating something more... well, maybe an adjustment in expectations is in order. Perfectly acceptable as a conceptual exercise, but make sure you swallow that grain of salt before viewing.
summary: Generic, Cruise-Helmed Sci-Fi That's More Concerned with Impressive Visuals Than Fresh Thoughts
Title: N/A

reviewText: Oblivion (2013) - Tom Cruise, Olga Kurylenko, Andrea Riseborough, Morgan Freeman, Melissa Leo and Nikolaj Coster-WaldauPremise: After an alien invasion, the Earth has been left a nuclear wasteland. Survivors gather aboard the TET in preparation to leave to a new colony on Titan. Before they can make the journey, resources such as water need to be harvested if there's to be any chance for survival: Enter Jack Harper, Tech 49 (Tom Cruise), who with his partner Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) protect drones designed to find and kill "Scavs" - the remnant alien survivors of the invasions who carry out attacks on the resource gatherers. When a mysterious woman (Olga Kurylenko) crash lands on the planet though, everything Jack thought he knew is called into question...Thoughts: High definition brought out the best in this visually arresting film. The musical score (by M83) is intense, awesome but, at times, a bit overpowering/jarring in certain sequences. The acting is very well done, but unfortunately the film's script and story lacks the calibre of its talent. The story meanders, there are nonsensical plot twists which are not explored for anything but shock value. As a result, at times the film can be quite frustrating. Additionally, not all the characters are developed well - specifically Nikolaj Coster-Waldau's supporting character who - though bad ass - doesn't get developed beyond "bad ass with long hair and a gun." But each actor does their best to bring something to the table and it shows - though it isn't enough to cover the plot holes and lack of development at times.Should you buy this film: My experience was watching the film in true IMAX. As such, the visuals were incredible - if you have a High Def television and a surround sound system, then I definitely recommend this film on bluray. Anything less, you're being robbed. At the same time: this film is NOT on the same level as a smaller indie film which covers a lot of the same ground in different ways. If you're looking for quality science fiction, I recommend Duncan Jones' Moon starring Sam Rockwell. However, if you're looking for a beautifully shot action adventure film with a great soundtrack, Oblivion would probably be a good call.

reviewText: Like any movie, YMMV.  For instance, my lady friend didn't just dislike this movie.  She hated it, even though she really likes Tom Cruise.  Then again, there are very few movies with a sci-fi theme that she thinks is worthwhile.  It's simply not her cup of tea.  And while it's not her most hated sci-fi movie ("Prometheus" probably gets that honor), there was nothing she liked about "Oblivion".There are many outstanding reviews that I've read here (especially M. Oleson's) that give intricate and informative details on the storyline, so I'll take a slightly different approach.  Obviously, I really liked "Oblivion" (I also liked "Prometheus"), and for several reasons.  First, I enjoyed the story -- one major and a few minor plot holes not withstanding.  Oh, we've seen variations of this story many times, but that doesn't mean I lost interest.  There were times I knew it was purposely oblique, but thought it stood up really well when taken in total.  This is the type of movie where a second viewing may be warranted (I've watched it multiple times).  Secondly, the picture quality is absolutely top tier, stark and pristine … and so were the sets.  In a word, stunning!  Thirdly, the soundtrack.  It's an incredible, soaring soundtrack throughout that really pulls you in and doesn't let go.  And finally, the depth of the bass.  This movie will shake your walls and slam your body hard (if one has the equipment) with clean, powerful bass.  There is one scene where they use a bass sweep that hits single digits (below 10 Hz) that will put a smile on just about any face.  This Blu-Ray's sound capability will far surpass what any theater can reproduce (even the Arclight in Hollywood).  Theaters simply can't plumb the depths that a well-integrated home theater with powerful subwoofers can, nor do they try.  It's simply not feasible to try and reach anything below 30 Hz due to the sheer volume of a large theater.Rating:Picture quality:  10 out of 10 (I have never seen better)Sound quality:  10 out of 10 (did I mention the incredible bass and the impressively soaring and dramatic score?)Story and presentation:  marginal 7 out of 10 (I had a few issues with parts of the storyline)Overall: marginal 9 out of 10 (which means that I highly recommend it)Summary:  If you like sci-fi and have a nice home theater with some potent subwoofers, I can't think of a better movie to showcase.  As an example, "War of the Worlds" is renown for its impressively potent and stellar bass (DVD and Blu-Ray are equally as good and rated 5-stars on AVS), and "Oblivion" (Blu-Ray) is just as impressive.

reviewText: Here is Tom Cruise's latest movie in a single sentence: It's "WALL-E" with a heavy dose of "Moon" and "Total Recall," and a touch of "The Matrix" and/or "Terminator."If you've seen these movies -- and most other sci-fi from the last thirty years -- "Oblivion" will seem oddly familiar. Admittedly, being derivative isn't necessarily a death blow to a movie. But being dull and spiritless is -- and while director Joseph Kosinski crafts a truly beautiful, brilliant post-apocalyptic world to play in, he never crafts a story or characters half as interesting.Sixty years ago, an alien invasion was repelled... but not before they destroyed the moon... which seems to have just made Earth temporarily inhospitable rather than permanently lifeless. The human race has evacuated to Titan, and the only ones left are a "clean-up crew" who live in an iHouse high in the clouds, and use drones to exterminate the alien "scavs."WALL-E... sorry, I mean Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) is regularly sent out to repair drones, but he's more interested in the ruined remnants of human civilization. But one day he finds cryo-pods from a crashed ship, and barely manages to save one of the survivors, Julia (Olga Kurylenko) -- whom he recognizes from half-recalled memories.While trying to help her out, Jack stumbles across a small band of surviving humans, led by Beech (Morgan Freeman) -- and he finds that they are planning to blow up the TET, a human space station. When Jack refuses, Beech sends him off on a quest to discover the truth rather than... well, just telling him what's going on.Joseph Kosinski has only done two movies, but he's already developing a distinct style: bland story and gorgeous visuals. "Oblivion" is a truly beautiful movie, with sweeping views of an Earth that has been completely devastated, but is slowly being reclaimed by nature. The only oasis is the cold, sterile iHouse, set in a perpetually rosy cloudbank atop a slender pillar. It leaves you thinking that Kosinski has dreamed up designs for the entire planet, and just wants to tour his postapocalyptic world.Unfortunately, the plot is a Frankenstein's monster of other sci-fi movies. Almost everything in this movie has been done better elsewhere, either directly ripping it off ("Moon") or in cliche form (oh dearie me, what IS the connection between Julia and Jack?). And there's no passion or energy behind anything that happens -- it all feels bland and generic.And Kosinski is just awful at expositing anything that ISN'T ripped off from those other movies. Major plot twists flew directly over my head because of how blandly they were revealed -- for example, the big reveal involving the TET.Sadly the characters are just as bland and generic as the story. Tom Cruise is basically playing the Generic Tom Cruise Action Hero here -- a good, morally-upright guy who has some murky stuff in his past. Even the character's NAME sounds like a GTCAH name. Cruise gives a decent performance, but he's definitely not stepping outside his action-hero box -- and the character is so blandly nondescript he probably couldn't even if he wanted to.None of these characters have pasts, quirks, other relationships, or anything to really flesh them out -- they're as blandly uninteresting as the plot.. Kurylenko is pretty awful, Freeman is phoning it in, and Melissa Leo and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau aren't given enough to do. The only really good performance is Andrea Riseborough as Harper's lover/partner, who is made pretty miserable by his attraction to Julia. But alas, she also is not given much to do, and is gotten rid of when she becomes inconvenient."Oblivion" is a visually entrancing movie, but the Frankenstein plot left me feeling empty and bored. Directed by someone other than Kosinski, it might have been an astounding film... but instead we just get a bland, forgettable one.

reviewText: No action-adventure movie should held to the standard of a "Citizen Kane."  The genre is akin to a roller coaster ride: it provides entertaining thrills. There are of course minimum requirements for performances, dialogue, plot, and special effects. Oblivion achieve all in a workmanlike manner.  It may not be the finest of its type and it's not 100% original, but it's entertaining and far from the worst.  The CGI's are stunning, and the action proceeds logically.Rottentomatoes gave it a 54% positive rating, marginally failing to achieve their "fresh" rating.  Perversely, Ridley Scott's muddled and illogical creature-feature, "Prometheus" was rated a 74% positive.  That should arguably call into question the reviewers' credibility.

Those three add up to a five star rating right there. Add in Tom Cruise who 9 outa 10 times somehow doesn't fail to put out an amazing film (I just don't know how he does it, but he simply puts out "Good Film' over & over! TYVM Tom Cruise!) If you love Sci-Fi movies for Sci-Fi movie's sake, the see this movie. If you plan to nit-pic, then maybe this movie is not for you. Plan on a beautiful ride, though. 'Thumbs up'.

reviewText: Tom Cruise is a futuristic astronaut of sorts salvaging the rest of earth’s resources after some big war with Aliens. Humans win the war, but the earth is unlivable, so everyone packs up and goes to some other planet or moon or something, I forget, but its atmosphere is compatible for us. Or is that what’s going on? It keeps you guessing enough to be interested and answers your question sufficiently at the end. You do wonder what the heck is really going on here for a good part of the movie, but it’s not so confusing that you lose interest. The concept kind of reminds me of After Earth, but Oblivion is better and takes an interesting turn whereas After Earth is pretty boringly straight forward. Say what you want to about Tom Cruise, he does get pretty good rolls and he does a pretty good job in the end. I was satisfied with the explanation and I Morgan Freeman and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau, from Game of Thrones were good in it, but Morgan Freeman is great I everything. Don’t expect anything to terribly deep and I think you will enjoy this one.

reviewText: This film relays heavily on an intriguing story line. This approach works well - you are around half way through the film before you can really start to understand what is going on and have a feel for the plot line. This movie doesn't move particularly quickly, and the slow methodical approach defines the film. The graphics and the world they create are pretty incredible. Despite the graphics and special effects the winding plot makes the movie more thought provoking than many post apocalyptic Sci-fi type movies. I enjoyed the acting as well. Tom Cruise plays Jack Harper, a repair technician tasked with repairing drones on a largely decimated planet earth. His character evolves the most throughout the film. Morgan Freeman also play and interesting role.The bottom line is that this was an average film. I enjoyed watching it but I will not be in a hurry to watch again. The plot dragged at times and the ending was not satisfying in my opinion.
summary: Interesting Sci-fi film - under performs it's potential

reviewText: Michael Phillips, movie reviewer for the Chicago Tribune, didn't much care for this film. That I respect his work a lot put me in a position. Do I see it on the big screen or wait for the DVD release? I forked over me money at the cinema and I'm glad I did.Here's the scoop. Earth was attacked by some aliens. We won the war but killed the planet in the process. Earth folk have migrated to Titan and Jack, (Tom Cruise) and his controller cum sidekick Victoria (Andrea Riseborough), are left behind to maintain the flying drones that guard the massive Hydrogen converters against attack by the scavengers, those who chose not to go to Titan. Jack also has a recurring dream of a particular woman who he somehow thinks he might know. Jack gets caught by the scavengers and he finds out the world might not be set up quite the way he was told.OK. OK. Yes there are some things that were borrowed. And some other things that should throw up red flags for the viewer early on. But this is still a heck of a watch. The director's, Joseph Kosinski, first outing, "Tron Legacy", was not really very good. He's taken a huge leap forward here. This is a sweeping film with large scope, great camera movement and faster, more assured, pacing. I did not know where the story was headed and that's a good thing. Too often a movie telegraphs itself. This looked good, had great sets, good effects, good sound, music, editing and all the other production values in line with a project this size. Cruise is aging well. He plays a somewhat cocky character but not quite as severe as "Top Gun's" Maverick. Olga Kurylenko is a rising star, and her sweet, appeal works well here. Morgan Freeman is becoming Morgan Freeman so there aren't any real surprises there.I was a bit confused on some aspects of the script but my guess is they'd be cleared up with a second viewing. But if you are a big fan of big sci-fi movies, this should fill your plate.
summary: A Must See for Sci-Fi Fans

reviewText: Universal Studios Home Entertainment brings "Oblivion" to Blu-ray and DVD for those who didn't get a chance to see it in theaters. Many people find Tom Cruise to be an acquired taste these days after his couch-jumping antics and Scientology beliefs became public knowledge. However, this beautiful sci-fi gem shouldn't be pushed away solely because he's the lead actor.Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) and his partner, Victoria (Andrea Riseborough), are the last remaining humans on the war-torn Earth. They're assigned to watch over powerful machines used to collect what's left of the planet's natural resources for use on a moon being colonized by the survivors of an alien invasion. As the job is wrapping up and it grows closer to time for them to leave and move on to their new lives, bizarre dreams and occurrences awaken Jack's suspicions about his mission and who he is.Although the story isn't completely unique, "Oblivion" manages to borrow different concepts from several classic sci-fi films and blends them together to create something new and entertaining. Director Kosinski does a great job of paying homage to the genre, bringing to mind the visually stunning films of the 1970s and 1980s such as "2001: A Space Odyssey," "Alien," and "Outland.""Oblivion" is rated PG-13 for violence, adult language, and sexual situations. There's really nothing too horribly objectionable to be found. The box art states there's some nudity, but I didn't see where any actual body parts were shown.The audio and video presentations for "Oblivion" will leave home audiences stunned. The crystal clear picture shows off the different landscapes and familiar monuments which have been laid waste by war. M83's score brings every sequence of drama and action to life through an immaculate 7.1 surround sound mix.There are a few special features found on the Blu-ray version of "Oblivion." Audio commentary is provided by Director Joseph Kosinski and actor Tom Cruise. "Promise of a New World" is a 5-part "Making of" documentary that clocks in at 48 minutes. We also get four deleted and alternate scenes. A 5.1 surround presentation of M83's isolated score is included as well."Oblivion" is an exciting mix of blockbuster action and sci-fi intellect. It's well-acted and serves as a tribute to the groundbreaking genre films of the past. An elegant audio and video feature presentation coupled with some satisfying special features makes this a worthy purchase for consumers.
summary: "Oblivion" Blu-ray Brings Smart Sci-Fi Action Home

reviewText: This film is just simple enough to be predictable at times, but the sense of adventure is sustained.  It is well written and well acted enough to be compelling.  I hesitated to watch this now that we know how crazy Tom Cruise is, but he's still a good fit for a role like this.  (I would like to think this film might become an allegory for his personal disillusionment regarding the church of Scientology, his struggle against himself, and ultimate renouncement of the crazy).  A lot of the fun of sci-fi is in the gadgets, and here they do not disappoint.  Those drones are actually scary, and their domicile is like a preview of the iHouse (they live in an iPad, haha).I would have liked to see more exploration of the human element, but there wouldn't have been a lot of room for that in what's basically a "what-if-our-stuff-was-stolen" on a grand scale tale.  Bottom line, it's fun, and I would watch it again.

reviewText: This is visually stunning SF. While I was watching it I was so grateful someone actually invested the money to make this film because it is that rare film you can just turn the sound off (or play only the soundtrack) and give the eyes a feast.Tom Cruise gets a bad rap, and I think unfairly, because of some of his 'antics' and his religion. I don't really care about either. His antics have never hurt anyone and, so far as I know, his religion hasn't either. Yes, I know there are allegations of abuse but that is true of any religion and any atheist group, as well.But he delivers yet again another terrific performance, something he has done more consistently than any actor over the past 30 years. The rest of the cast, but I have to point out maybe the most surprising performance in the film and right up there with Cruise, that of Andrea Riseborough as Victoria.I think the 'scavs' were a disappointment, however, and that is why I take off half a star.Yes, Morgan Freeman is good but they never seemed real to me within the confines of the universe the director had created. Small criticism since they really aren't as prominent as they should have been but no spoilers here. I was able to watch the film without any foreknowledge and I enjoyed it as such. I wouldn't want to ruin that for anyone.The ending? There are great and surprising moments leading up to the penultimate scene in the film. It is an odd scene which is by turns stunning and somewhat pedantic. It didn't rise up to the level of the expectations I had built. But I enjoyed the ride so much getting there that I didn't matter. And I have to admit I did enjoy the very final scene even though I saw it coming.The extras are very good. Tom Cruise is always interesting in his commentaries as he is here with the director. He is not just an actor playing a part. He puts real thought into the film and has great appreciation for everything involved in making a film as a skill.

reviewText: This sci-fi thriller unfolds like a novel, with a deliberate pace, each revelation building upon the other. Jack Harper is part of a two person team left behind on a desolated Earth after a war against an alien race. Mankind has relocated to Titan. Jack and his partner's job is to maintain the drones that protect the power generators sucking energy from Earth's oceans to power life on faraway Titan. Neither Jack nor his partner have a memory more than five years old, but Jack is haunted by dreams of a previous life, dreams that focus on a beautiful woman and visions of Earth before the war. Soon we begin to see that all is not as it seems.Despite the measured pace, the stunning visuals hold your interest: visually this film is a triumph. There are enough big action scenes to keep it exciting, although the movie begins to look familiar in parts, paying homage to Star Wars, Independence Day, The Matrix, and any post-apocalyptic thriller you've ever seen (I'm talking about you, Mad Max).This movie requires you to think and remember in order to understand the final revelations, so if you aren't the sort of person who likes puzzle movies, you might want to avoid this one.
summary: Intriguing and Stimulating, Not for All Tastes

reviewText: Over the course of the last few years, the science fiction genre of film has either provided major hits or complete misses.  Depending on who's acting and who's directing, movie-goes appear to be fairly picky about which sci-fi films they're willing to spend their money on.  In 2012, Prometheus took us back to the Aliens universe with critical and commercial success, while at the same time, Battleship and John Carter sank - ultimately drowning in a sea of misery.  Speaking of sci-fi success, Tom Cruise has been a part of a handful of lucrative sci-fi endeavors, including Minority Report, Vanilla Sky, and War of the Worlds.  Now, Tom Cruise is back once again with another pre-summer box office smash, Oblivion.Directed by Joseph Kosinski (Tron: Lecacy), Oblivion stars Tom Cruise as Jack Harper, one of the few remaining survivors of the planet earth - half of which has been destroyed and deemed uninhabitable after a nuclear war with an alien species, known as Scavs (Scavengers).  Harper, along with his partner and love interest, Victoria (Andrea Riseborough), are in charge of an operation to salvage and extract the last of earth's natural resources, prior to leaving earth and rejoining their fellow humans on a massive space station, called Titan.  However, everything is not as it seems when Jack saves a woman, Julia (Olga Kurylenko) from the wreckage of a crash-landing - the same woman whom he has been having recurring memories and dreams.  And, after making contact with the Scavs, Jack must uncover the secrets behind the organization for which he has been working and the reasoning behind his absent memory (which was mandatorily removed) .  Morgan Freeman and Melissa Leo also star in supporting roles.First and foremost, do not leave the theater when you see this film - and you absolutely should see this film.  Oblivion is one of the films that will require your attention at all times, because it's extremely easy to miss a giant piece of the puzzle during a bathroom break or popcorn run.  The film's plot is relatively easy to decipher by the conclusion of the film, however, there's more going on in this film that you can possibly interpret in one sitting.  The introduction of the film crams a whole lot of information into your head to set up the present conundrum being tackled by Cruise's character, Jack Harper.  Clearly, he's involved in a snatch-n-grab job, hastily attempting to remove earth's resources, while attempting to avoid any difficulties or interaction with the supposed villains, the Scavs.  However, it's impossible to get specific about the majority of the film's plot points without spoiling the film.Oblivion's cast is one of the most impressive features in this film and remains tremendously authentic from beginning to end in this enigmatic drama.  Tom Cruise hasn't been this enjoyable in quite a long time and really finds his groove with his character.  Reminiscent of the character from War of the Worlds, Jack Harper is mostly in the dark about the majority of the occurrences in this film and is often in over his head - yet somehow always manages to come out of each dire situation unscathed.  On the other hand, his partner (Victoria) constantly finds new ways to be jealous in a world where she has absolutely no competition.  At times, she can become an annoyance, but that's mostly due in large part to lack of her unwillingness to think outside the box (which is reserved solely for Tom Cruise's character).  Finally, let's face the fact here - everything is better with Morgan Freeman.By far and away, the most enjoyable moments of the film revolve around the CGI action sequences - which include some very intriguing and well-designed drones.  These drones are the main agitators in a rather Empire Strikes Back-like flight batter which is also a nice flashback to Tom Cruise sitting in a cockpit in Top Gun.  It's unclear whether or not the filmmakers meant to create a throwback sci-fi Top Gun-style chase scene, but regardless, this specific flight chase will have you wishing for a Top Gun sequel (which was sadly cancelled after the death of its original director, Tony Scott).Overall, there's absolutely nothing in Oblivion that hasn't been done in some other sci-fi before it.  Sure, it would be easy to say this is just another post-apocalyptic film with alien invaders, ultimately forcing humanity to unite for a greater good to defeat them.  Yet, this film is much more complex than your average space-invaders film.  It provides a busier (occasionally confusing) than usual plot (in Prometheus fashion), so if you look away, you'll most likely miss something important.  But, if you play close enough attention to the plot points, you'll be able to tie everything together in a nice, pretty bow when the credits role - hopefully coming to the conclusion that Oblivion is a perfectly fun and enjoyable sci-fi film.Overall Film Grade:  A-FNDNreview.com
summary: Sci-fi Top Gun for Cruise in Oblivion

reviewText: I confess that the negative critics kept me from experiencing OBLIVION on the big screen and the mentioning of an "alien invasion" didn't exactly stimulate my appetite for Joseph Kosinski's hors d'oeuvre (IMHO, there is only one thing that alien beings might find interesting about our planet, and surprisingly the film got that right dead-on). But fortunately one of my friends insisted that I "wanted" to see the film and he was right.Many critics claimed that OBLIVION was supposedly derivative and built on sci-fi tropes. I couldn't agree less. Joe Kosinski was never cagey about OBLIVION being an homage to the science fiction films of the 1960's and 1970's (PLANET OF THE APES and THE OMEGA MAN come to mind) and used elements and ideas from these works. But here he created something completely different, original and fresh out of these (and never at the expense of the original work like the shameless "copy and paste" of BEN HUR's chariot race in a highly anticipated movie from 1999), resulting in a film much larger than the mere sum of its parts.On the contrary, Kosinski uses these elements and ideas as subtle hints that appearances are deceiving to tell a science fiction story in the best tradition of THE TWILIGHT ZONE, renowned for its unsuspecting story turns and twists. By the end of the film it should be abundantly obvious that the drones were neither inspired by Pacman or WALL-E but rather by a remote-controlled device in one of these films from the last century.Admittedly, watching the film for the first time reveals what appears to be a couple of plot holes but basically these are necessary evils not to give the surprising twist away. Watching the film for the second time and from the inevitable new perspective things start to make a lot of sense and Olga Kurylenko's acting, now that audiences can fully understand what her Julia character must have gone through upon her awakening, is quite impeccable and reveals how skillful Joe Kosinski uses body language (something I had already admired in his previous film TRON: LEGACY) to tell what's going on inside his characters.OBLIVION is presented in stunning vistas and in a cinematographic style that takes the time to tell the story without the hectic pace that often plagues contemporary movies. The Blu-ray looks fantastic, the level of detail and textures is remarkable, colors are natural and the sound design is impressive, giving the drones a unique personality and language (their "I require assistance" beacon sound will get quite a different meaning during the course of the story...).The film is enigmatic and thrilling during the first viewing, much clearer and evident the second time, and if you still require insight there's Tom Cruise's and Joe Kosinski's inartificial audio commentary for the entire length of the film. If you buy a film on video disc for repeated viewing, experience and enjoyment, then OBLIVION is most definitely my Number One recommendation during these days.If you're looking for fast-paced sci-fi action comic-strip-style I'd say that the latest STAR TREK reboot movie will be more to your liking. OBLIVION has plenty of good action scenes and visual eye candy (and can do without gore) but here these don't cover up the lack of an original story but rather serve to tell one that's good, thrilling and fresh. It's a passionate accomplishment I found incredibly entertaining and rewarding.
summary: The most underrated science fiction film of the early 21st Century

reviewText: They should turn the concept of this movie into a TV series.  I think it is just that good!  I find myself watching this movie over and over (like I do with the Star Wars movies).  You can tell this movie was done with a lot of pride and attention to detail--that goes for the crew and the cast both.  And the musical scoring is powerful, in my opinion.  The visual effects--let's just say "eye candy!"  They're so excellent!  All of this is why I keep putting the disc back into my BD player for continued encore performances!!  The picture quality of this BD is stunning!  The sound quality is uber-fantastic if you have a DTS-HD Master Audio A/V receiver with a 7.1-channel surround sound system.  The soundtrack has great lows (the windows in the house vibrate on certain scenes).  I'd recommend this movie to anybody--especially if you like sci-fi and action!  This movie is underrated.  It's a glorious gem!

reviewText: I just watched this movie on Blu-ray, and I was very, very impressed. Visually speaking, this is the type of Blu-ray that makes me lean forward in my seat, the sights are so eye-popping. The rendering of a post-apocalyptic earth afflicted by nuclear winter is strangely beautiful, as is the way in which the story is presented. Those who dislike Tom Cruise will not be able to move past his presence (he is in virtually every frame of this two hour movie), but for those who are interested in a unique, mind-bending sci-fi spectacular... you are in for a treat!
summary: Artistic, visually arresting, and in a way - beautiful

reviewText: Tom Cruise has a reputation for super action.  This movie is not that.  Don't get me wrong.  Stuff does splode real good but this is a more cerebral sci-fi.  It isn't perfect, though I couldn't tell you anything that I would recommend changing.  Perhaps it is the certain level of bleakness inherent in the tale that leaves an after taste.  I am glad that I watched it and I can recommend it wholeheartedly if you enjoyed movies like Blade Runner, Matrix or the early parts of The Island.  Tom Cruise is making some interesting moves these days.  I wrote him off. . .for reasons that don't need to be expounded. . .but after Jack Reacher, Rock of Ages and Oblivion I'm now more of a fan interested in seeing what kinds of choices he makes next. As an actor and a brand he has a lot more life left in him.

reviewText: This is my first new science fiction movie I've seen in quite a while, and was well-worth viewing. The entire cast did a good job with acting performance, and visual and sound effects are excellent. In comparison to other science fiction movies such as Independence Day, the action in this one is much slower, but entertains from start to finish. The story is intriguing, and I was content with the part that Tom Cruise played. I've seen him in other science fiction movies, and his acting fits well within this thrilling story. There is enough events going on throughout the film to hold your attention, along with suspense for the final conclusion. Overall, enjoyable and highly entertaining. Recommended to all those who enjoy thrilling, science fiction movies!

reviewText: (Some spoilers).Cruise cannot, has not and will never get a handle on acting! So this review is not about him. If you can get by his mundane, expressionless dialogue and haphazard expressions to the camera...perhaps you can just ignore him. This movie is built around two things...the excellent sci-fi premise i.e. storyline and the exceptional concept photography. The concept of a post-apocalyptic Earth is well-described here in a majestic manner and we are taken on an aerial tour to enhance the awe factor. The screenplay is written backwards, as are most mysteries; offering us present realizations and working up to the actual causes. Most alien-visitation flics have dealt with actual aliens. This deals with a robotic alien entity bent on the overall anniliation of the human race. Although acting is not stellar, it is adequate to carry the basic premise. The robotic hardware is incredibly believable and creates an awe factor. Eighty percent action and twenty percent character interaction makes an OK mix for an action film. Overall...quite entertaining and it does make you think; the sign of a memorable film!
summary: Excellent story line with surreal cinematography!

reviewText: At this point, I've seen this movie three times (twice in a "normal" theater and once in IMAX). That might give you a hint as to where I'm going with this.First a quick disclaimer: I loved Tron Legacy (also directed by Joseph Kosinksi who directs this film), partially because of nostalgia but more because I absolutely loved two aspects of the film which are present here as well: the beautiful visuals of the production's design and the epic soundtrack from Daft Punk. I wasn't too sure I'd love Oblivion but it looked cool (big Sci-Fi fan) and had a nice bit of mystery about what's really going on in the trailers.I will keep this spoiler-free as I think the events of the movie and where it goes are part of the fun.The basic plot summary is Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) and Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) are part of a team that's left on Earth to help with "clean-up" after the Earth was devastated by an alien invasion. The world is barely recognizable and most of the survivors (save for Jack and Victoria) are either on Titan or on the space station orbiting the planet called the Tet. The pair work on watching over the drones that are guarding huge water collectors that are pulling Earth's oceans to take with the remaining humans to Titan. Jack is the technician who flies in a dragonfly-shaped ship running patrols and rescuing downed drones. The drones are there and are being downed by a remaining contingent of the alien invasion that are scattered about the planet. As the commercials said, we won the war but lost the planet. Victoria acts as Jack's controller, using telemetry to help Jack while relaying orders coming from the Tet's mission controller.The rest you'll have to find out by watching.The film itself, as I said, was beautiful. Everything from the landscapes to the architecture of the tower the duo reside in are just visually stunning. They filmed much of the outdoor scenes in Iceland with its large expanses of desolate arctic tundra and volcanic soil. The director, Joseph Kosinksi, has a background in architecture and it shows in the designs of the tower and vehicles.The story is based on a graphic novel that the director had written and was talking about after Tron Legacy's release. Another reason I love the film is tied to my love for William Gibson's novels. I'm a big fan of concise dialog. There isn't a lot of hand-holding here. And while the story makes sense if you're open to it the first time through, watching it a second time helps as you'll realize why a certain character was a bit distant and laughed awkwardly at a specific moment. Ignore people going on about the reality of the environment and such...it's a movie people. I won't go into those sorts of things here (though I'm happy to discuss in the comments where people can't see...just no rants please). Just know that there are a couple of twists on the way to the conclusion that turn things on its head.The music was composed by M85 with the help of Joseph Trapanese and it's a great electronic ride. I've got the album (off iTunes) and personally I like to remove the "incidental" pieces that were obviously specific to a scene (I guess they all are but some are just better off in a movie and not blaring from your speakers). Even so, there are a lot of good pieces (I love Waking Up and a couple others I won't mention since the names could give away something...) and even though I'm not typically a fan of vocals over some of these great pieces, the one track with vocals has been winning me over each time I hear it.As the director himself put it, he wanted to create an environment that was "desolate but beautiful" as a sort of 180 from Tron Legacy where everything was dark but colorful. I think he did a great job. I love the fact that he used giant screens projecting video his crew filmed at the top of Haleakala (volcano) in Maui surrounding the tower set so the clouds you see are real, not CGI. That plus the tower set was lit with the light from those projections so you really feel like they're living in a tower above the clouds.On the acting front, honestly, don't expect Oscar-winning performances. I'm not saying they're bad, I'm just saying this isn't Schindler's List. Tom Cruise does a great job playing his character but I think it's more because the character fits him than because he's pulling a Daniel Day Lewis and transforming himself. The other characters play their roles well (hello Morgan Freeman) and Game of Thrones fans will get a small treat from a Lannister.That all said, please ignore the critics' reviews. I read through a bunch and they were all saying the same thing...that the movie wasn't original. That it didn't break new ground in anything and blah blah. It annoys me to no end when I read reviews by these people who do nothing but review movies (nice job!) and somehow expect every movie that comes out needs to be never-before-seen and every performance needs to be some sort of incredible experience that goes into history annals and gets taught at film school. The movie tells a story that's original even if elements are going to be similar to other stories (c'mon, science fiction has been around for generations we've covered most of it). The director does a great job of putting it all together and explaining the parts that need explaining.Unless you absolutely hate any of the actors (especially Tom Cruise since he's central to much of the story) or aren't really a fan of sci-fi (though I'd argue the science fiction aspects really don't matter beyond being tools to tell a fictional story), this should be an enjoyable watch. If you're unsure, feel free to rent it first because as with all things, there are many opinions and what I like may be what you hate.If you liked the style of Tron Legacy, are a fan of Tom Cruise in general, like sci-fi, or all of the above, definitely go for this movie. If not, rent it and decide. I think the marketing of the movie might have hurt it a bit (along with those critic reviews) since this is not that much of an action film. It's more thoughtful. Hopefully you'll enjoy it.
summary: Beautiful, visual film with an equally beautiful score
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's based on a comic. In this case, that's a bug, not a feature. The silliness of the plot shows this.It's interesting to start with. The moon has been destroyed by Scavengers, who forced humanity to nuke the earth to bits. Some humans are left on earth to guard the conversion of seawater into energy to enable migration to Titan. Scavs attack these installations from time to time.Or so we are told.Now, this crucial operation is left to a scattering of humans with extremely limited defense resources - and throughout the movie you ask yourself, why? Doesn't make sense, even when you find out what's really going on.You already guessed the true nature of the Scavs. The mystery of what really happened is also compelling. But the story - even its big twist - unfolds sloooooowwwwwly. There are scenes which should have been edited out for time. In one egregious example, a proposal scene is described ... THEN THEY SHOW IT TO YOU just in case you missed it. Things just take too long to happen. But the worst is yet to come.The ending is, basically, (SPOILER ALERT) ... Independence Day, only infinitely stupider. Yes,that's right. The aliens who destroyed THE MOON are too clueless to stop one man with a nuke ... An advanced, predatory alien species with the capabilities of interstellar travel and moon-rending allows an already suspect quisling of a defeated race into their inner sanctum with nary a TSA patdown ... Why not just trot the writer onto the screen and pie-face him for not having any believable ideas on how to end it all?. (SPOILER ENDS)It's a shame. Morgan Freeman looks a goof in his round shades. The first plan to nuke the alien ship doesn't make sense (why escort the bomb out? Don't you just program and release it?). And with their resources, surely the aliens could have come up with a better defense plan involving, oh, I don't know, lots of armed, automated machines?Great CGI, great landscapes of catastrophic devastation, some nice futuristic home design. But ultimately idiotic.Update: Stupidity abounds. Searching for a downed probe is better done on a motorbike instead of a cool copter? Why? Recovery and repairs are routinely done with woefully inadequate defenses. Why? And on it goes.Speaking of the end, an earth with no moon is basically unfit for life due to many, many parameters, but let's not even go there.I liked their pug-faced, endearing killer drone design, the copter and their nice house, but that doesn't tip the scales enough.

reviewText: I missed seeing this movie in the theater where it would have been the best viewed but the blu-ray is stunning. If you are into sci-fi, you will enjoy this movie. Also, if you are a Tom Cruise fan, you will love it as he dominates the screen throughout the movie. The story is good, the acting very good, and the cinematography and music is outstanding.As we enter the digital age, we may see the end of blu-ray, dvd, etc but if Hollywood wants to continue to sell physical medium, then this is how you sell a product. The blu-ray menu is nice, the features very good but what makes this blu-ray standout is the isolated soundtrack. I love that feature and I have only one other movie like this which was a dvd. You won't get this with a digital copy. The movie studios should continue this and if they could bundle the soundtrack on CD with the movie and charge an extra $5.00, I think that would be a great idea. One of the Ghost In The Shell movies came bundled with the soundtrack CD and I was impressed. This movie is diffiently worth the current $20.00 price.

reviewText: What an overblown stinker! To be completely honest, I have only seen the 2D version on Pay-per-view. It's probably better in 3D. The visuals are stunning but haven't we become blase about this sort of thing in this day and age? I know I have. I still want a story that I can follow and one that will hold my interest. This movie is L-O-N-G, so long and so dull that I had to watch it over two days because it was putting me to sleep. Morgan Freeman gives us another elder-statesman type part. Didn't I just see him in Olympus has fallen playing the same character? Well, I guess at his age, he needs the money. Tom Cruise is getting OLD! They try unsuccessfully to squeeze tears out of you by using such touches as Procul Harem's "Whiter Shade of Pale" and several shots of Andrew Wyeth's CHRISTINA'S WORLD. I'd rather stare at the Wyeth paiting for an hour or two than sit through  this turkey again.

reviewText: When you have seen as many movies as I have you tend to become jaded. You wonder if an original blockbuster-type movie will ever be made with genuine effort and a non-ironic purpose, especially in the sci-fi genre. You fear the day will never come. It is nice to be proven wrong.Oblivion is not a fantastic movie by any means. It has its problems. There are some inconsistencies and goofs here and there, but you can tell from the first few minutes that genuine thought and effort was put in to this movie, and that more than makes up for its other issues. There is a style and an atmosphere to it. In a time when green-screen rooms are substituted for real sets so often that you begin to worry for the livelihoods of studio carpenters, here is a film which "feels" real. These are sets and locations that, though parts of them were C.G., there was a seamless blending with the real that is a treat for computer weary eyes.Tom Cruise plays Jack Harper, a technician responsible for the maintenance and security of huge reactors that supply power to off-world colonists. Earth has been nearly destroyed by an invading alien force and, though humanity won the war, the planet is a wasteland. This is explained by a helpful (if annoying) voice over/scroll at the beginning of the film. Jack's only company is his communications officer Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) with whom he occasionally gets frisky. Their memories are periodically erased to protect vital off-world information in case of capture by the remnants of the alien force which they call "Scavs". In spite of their memory wipes Jack has flashes of his life from before the war, which worries him because the war ended sixty years ago, well before he was born.His companion tells him to focus on his work and not to worry. After all, they are leaving for the new colony in two weeks and they don't want to ruin their chance to rejoin humanity. The work continues as usual until an encounter with the Scavs and the discovery of a crashed spaceship shake everything Jack thinks he knows.From here we would enter into spoiler territory, so I will dispense with the exposition. Suffice it to say that what follows, while not perfect, at least shows true effort at the writing, acting, directing, and effects levels. The actors really care about what they are doing and it shows. Tom Cruise, of course, can only play Tom Cruise. His range is limited, but here it is well used. The mystery of the plot, while a little predictable, at least doesn't insult the viewer's intelligence. In a limited fashion the movie brings up questions about what it means to be human and what our purpose really is in the world. Though these issues are not delved into too deeply, it was nice to see them actually dealt with and not just used as cheap set pieces. The set designers and the director take care to create a world we can dive into and almost touch and taste. The sterility of Jack's base really contrasts with the grittiness of the devastated world below.The only items I would change are relatively minor. One is the opening scroll/narration. Opening scrolls may have been cool in Star Wars a few decades ago, but now they are a little dated and annoying. They are especially grating when read aloud to us and doubly so when you divulge the exact same information with dialogue not too long after. The other change would be to distinguish between the female leads physically a little better. Because of the washed out color scheme of the movie it is hard to tell the two women apart at times and it gets distracting. Is that her? No, wait. It's the other one. The fact that the two women are usually in different styles of clothing and in different locations helps, but it takes a while to get there.This is a movie well worth the effort put into it. It is good sci-fi with good execution and no franchise to prop it up. The studio went out on a limb by not playing it safe and finding something to reboot or a big name to tag a sequel onto. Here's hoping this movie gets a lot of attention and maybe we will see more of its kind in the future.

reviewText: This sci-fi flick was terrific. The space ship was a joy ride. Tom delivers yet another action-drama role in this post-apocalyptic tale.Unique story with grand scale and stellar visuals. Watching it the second time was more enjoyable, because I was more stimulated by the visuals the first time go through, the second time I was more in tune with the story line. Great balance between the two. Last but not least the soundtrack was amazing. One of the best I've heard in a sci-fi movie.

reviewText: I think this film is about 'mother issues', masquerading as the sci-fi. Freud had argued that the original sexual object for both sexes in the mother. In this film, our couple receives the orders from Sally, played by Melissa Leo. Sally is their mission commander, who is stationed on a space station that orbits the Earth. Sally is an older woman, a thinly-veiled representation of the mother. The ordeal of Jack (Tom Cruise) is to go through tests orchestrated by Sally and to become a man. He is to become Vika's "rescuer". Psychoanalysts know that a man can suddenly lose all sexual attractiveness for a woman from the moment that he shows some sort of complicity with her mother. Vika's case is complicated by a love triangle, but the essence of the movie is this: Jack had to quit any compliance with the mother (plus mother-in-law, Sally was all in one) in order to become a man and a husband, albeit to another women. I recommend this film - it's not bad.

reviewText: Finally, a decent sci-fi film that's not pushing some thinly-disguised social agenda (like Avatar, for example).  Plot was engaging and original without being overly complicated. Nice little twist at the very end (not giving it away). True, you sort of saw it coming, but you weren't 100% sure until the final scene.  Critics were merciless with Morgan Freeman and I don't know why; they used terms like "sleep-walking" or "just collecting his check".  The fact is, his character was purposely understated in the plot and not the prime focus of the film anyway -- sort of a transitional but still key character none the less.I LOVED that little jet-copter-thingy Cruise flew throughout much of the film -- way too cool! Kinda reminded me of that cool car he drove in the film Minority Report.  Whenever Tom Cruise is on the screen you can be assured there'll be plenty of cool gadgets & high tech stuff.If you like solid sci-fi sans the soppy social messages, then I think you'll enjoy this film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Planet Earth has supposedly been devastated by a war with 'aliens', and most of humanity is living off world on Saturn's Moon 'Titan'.  A few stay back to watch over and protect the 'power generators' sending the power back to the Titan Station.  You see transmissions between the maintenance crew and Titan, protecting and maintaining these power generators, and then these few are looking forward to joining 'Titan Earth' people.This movie has many refreshing twists.  I won't give them away.  Morgan Freeman pops up a little later... :)Overall, this is a wonderful remembering of what humanity is, was and how much we (I) appreciate the beauty of the Earth as it is.  Another aspect of this movie is that our memories and who we are, are much more than a mechanical, chemical, or robotic program.  Our being or spirit is instead a 'wholographic' and spiritual being, of memory... sorry, better not say more :)There are fun twists later in the movie... This is a movie to me that says "yes" to our humanity, care, empathy, and appreciation to the beauty of earth,... no to transhumanism and post humanism.  (Look it up)Beyond that, if you don't want to think about 'meanings' or 'morals of the story', it is a great movie of 'empowerment' facing massive odds.I loved this movie.
summary: A Film for Humanity in the Midst of 'Post Humanism'

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: This film is a fairy tale and I guarantee you it will end well. But it is also a patchwork of plagiarized elements.The earth was destroyed, a destruction caused by the destruction of the moon by some not really specified cosmic war. The earth then turned into a wasteland submerged by tons and tons of dust, earth and rocks. The ruins are thus underground. The Golden Gate Bridge is reduced to two pillar tips sticking out of that dirt. That's a rewriting of H.G. Wells the Time Machine.Two humans are living in the ring of satellites that overlook the waste land with a company of drones that are supposed to destroy all signs of life. Jack Harper is the man and the woman is supposed to be his wife. Jack Harper's memory has been erased to enable him to carry out his mission. Total Recall, second episode, the sequel. Everyday Jack Harper is supposed to go down on the surface to revive the drones that have been downed in the night. There is thus some kind of hostile life on this planet, living underground of course. That's Star Wars revisited. An underground resistance has been so often used that listing all the plagiarized connections would take many pages. That implies at this moment that the surviving humans who have fled the decaying planet are controlling the situation from some distant artificial planet. That is a black star like in Star Wars again. But who are these escapees?But memory-deprived Jack Harper knows where there is a secret valley that is as primeval as the Garden of Eden. There Jack Harper has a cabin with electricity and a pile of vinyl records and a record player and all kinds of heirloom  and he plays his records everyday when he manages to escape from the control of his "wife" on the surveillance satellite. The drones have never found that place. I guess Jack Harper's lost memory was not lost completely and the drones are not very swift.Then one day a spacecraft crushes on the surface and there are four or five sleep-boxes with hibernating human beings in them. This spacecraft was called by a strange signal from the underground resistance. The drones are destroying the sleep-pods. Jack Harper saves one and takes the woman inside to his satellite base. The reaction of his official wife shows there is a real problem there. When he takes the woman to recuperate the "black box" of the space craft they are captured by the resistance and then things become iffy.Let's have one more trip "Back to the Future" and then we have two Jack Harpers and maybe or maybe not two women and this saved woman (or her and her double) is revealed to be Jack Harper's real wife, two real wives and two real Jack Harpers. Then the initial Jack Harper recuperates some kind of memory. With the help of the resistance under attack from drones, he realizes that he has to fulfill the mission the other Jack Harper - but that is him in a way, at least if you accept the concept of doppelgangers - and  his wife were entrusted with: to destroy the black star.Officially one of his real wives is hidden in the secret valley, the other one is set in the sleep pod that is going to be delivered by one Jack Harper to the black star with a bomb in it. When he finally reaches his destination, o divine miracle, the wife has been swapped and replaced by the leader of the resistance who is dying of a wound gotten in the last battle against the drones. But the bomb is here, Jack Harper is determined and the final an massive attack of drones against the resistance is under way.What will happen? A happy happening and glorious ending of course. The black star crumbles, the drones are grounded, the resistance is saved, the wife has a child and two or three years later the surviving Jack Harper reaches the secret valley with the resistance and we are in a Grimm-like ending when they are happy ever after, ever after Snow White's step mother dies dancing in red-hot metal shoes.If you like soft horror fairy tales, rush to this one. Otherwise entrust it to your children who might have soft nightmares in the night. You will have to cuddle them with love.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU
summary: So many strings from so many places

reviewText: The movie "Oblivion" is a great movie to relax with if you are a post-apocalyptic science fiction fan. It starts out appearing as a story about a man/woman salvage team trying to gather resources from the destroyed earth to take with them to their satellite home where the last of humanity lives and then going to one of Jupiter's moons to restart civilization.  However appearances can be deceiving and it turns out that the world is not what it seems and they are not what they seem.  As the story goes on many secrets are revealed as to how the world was devastated and how Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) was involved in it.  I enjoyed the special effects and the action but one thing  made the film less enjoyable to me.  It was obvious at a certain point how the plot was going to resolve itself and the required happy ending was not that satisfying.  Still, it's a good flick and I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys this film genre.
summary: Tom Cruise sci-fi flick is a satisfying adventure
Title: N/A

reviewText: Oblivion is one of those movies where so many scenes are a potential bathroom break and if it were edited more aggressively could have been collapsed down to about an hour. The film opens on a 2 minute voice over from Tom explaining things to the audience, followed by a dialog desert for the next 30 minutes, then it twists into a frenzied, quasi love story that taps into Total Recall territory. It's a strangely soulness film, presumably to reflect the loneliness of living in the new world's reality, but as a result it's hard to connect to any of the major characters.Aside from the beautiful apartment in the sky that would send anyone with vertigo into a constant state of anxiety, the production design is fairly derivative of other sci-fi (Total Recall, Wall-E, the Matrix, etc.) Without giving too much away, there are fairly major plot holes and when they finally drop the big surprise, it's pretty clear that somebody thought that ripping off "Moon" as an action film would be a good idea. Although Oblivion looks good and it's a little more introspective than a typical Cruise blockbuster, it's ultimately a bit vapid and is easily forgettable.

reviewText: First of all, it should be noted that I am a HUGE lover of futuristic movies with aliens. The interesting plot, gorgeous landscapes, and CGI put this movie near the top of my most favorite movies. Despite it's less than stellar performance in theaters, I feel like this movie is quite undervalued.Quick Plot (No Spoilers): Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) is an engineer who has been tasked with maintaining a fleet of drones that are assisting in the salvaging of Earth in the year 2077, 60 years after a devastating alien attack. Humanity won the war with the aliens (called Scavs), but Earth was rendered uninhabitable in the process. Along with his partner Victoria (Andrea Riseborough), Jack counts down the days until their term on Earth will be finished and they can rejoin the rest of humanity on the space station Tet that orbits Earth and will leave for Saturn's moon Titan once salvage is complete. One day a mysterious spaceship crashes down to Earth and sends Jack down a path that will lead him to the horrifying truth of Tet and his own existence.

reviewText: "Based on a graphic novel" means another comic book-based story. I'm sure you expect subtle nuances and sophisticated philosophizing, but.... In this dystopian setting (of course) we visit the ruins of well-known American landmarks as our hero is sent to finish the eradication of a few survivors who cling to the remnants of Earth after an interplanetary war. The moon has been destroyed and we see the effects of the resulting earthquakes, while aliens "farm" the remaining water. Computer Generated Imaging is used very effectively, although some of this was shot in Iceland, California, New York and Louisiana. The Empire State Building is a critical element.It is impossible to talk about the plot without revealing important points, so rather than do an entire review that is a spoiler, I'll stay pretty general.We see:* Tom Cruise ("Jack Reacher" and "Rock of Ages") is more appealing than usual; this time he plays the stalwart soldier on assignment to "mop up" any survivors.* Morgan Freeman ("Olympus Has Fallen" and "Dolphin Tale"") is one of those survivors trying to avoid being "mopped up."* Nikolaj Coster-Waldau ("Headhunters" and "Game of Thrones") is currently my favorite Danish actor. His character is another one of those survivors attempting to remain alive on Earth.* Andrea Riseborough ("Disconnect" and "W.E.") is our hero's partner, sharing that mop-up assignment.* Olga Kurylenko ("Quantum of Solace" and "Paris je t'aime") is the survivor of a crash, rescued by our hero.* Melissa Leo ("The Fighter" and "Flight") is the Commander's voice and face on the communications screen, issuing orders to our mop-up crew.Pay close attention to the plot, as it is satisfactorily complex. I liked one "sink hole" that turned out to be the ruins of the New York City Library. Please note that this cast has been assembled in keeping with Tom Cruise's international stardom. His movies are successful throughout the world and they keep his fans in mind when his movies are cast. This is a very good one for him.This is rated PG-13, so expect lots and lots of gunfire, no sweaty bodies, a couple of swear words and nudity only alluded to, but the crux of the story is a "mind-wipe" that erases memory, so pay close attention. Amazon will notify me when the DVD is available.

reviewText: Oblivion is only a imaginative, more expressive enemy boss away from being a certified classic. The visuals, sound fx, acting and score are all first rate. Even the idea of Cruise as a lone patrolman/repairman is well conceived, as his character slowly evolves from an optimistic boy scout into a reluctant revolutionary. My one gripe with the film is that after spending much of the movie building toward a confrontation with the enemy and the truth, which happens to be one and the same, the director elects to represent the big baddie as a faceless, featureless, expressionless machine. Cold, calculating logic is lethal to be sure but it's also not very interesting and does not give us the memorable villain that this movie desperately deserved. From the previews I had hoped that Freeman was the bad guy since we never get to see him in such roles and I can't help but think that this plot twist is probably what begin to calm my wild expectations. The "scavs" are human? Really? Wow. That could only mean that the real aliens must really be repulsive, menacing, mesmerizing and unforgettable. Right? Wrong. 2001 was a great movie but the whole computer/robot/intelligent machine as the villain is a let down of the lowest order.

reviewText: Movie is visually stunning, acting was OK, special effects very good, plot was OK to good, but movie seemed to go on a bit too long. Integrating all this info gives about a 3.5 to 4.0 out of 5 stars. I am a sci fi fan, so I appreciated the rather slow start to this visually arresting movie. The plot is OK, but it does not take long to figure out what's going to happen if you've seen enough sci fi flicks. Special effects were very good also. I found the ending kind of "fakey" and somewhat abrupt however. Would these smart aliens/extra terrestrials/or their intelligence or computer technology not see what's coming ahead of time? After all, they tricked the earth and its people into becoming a wasteland, thereby feeding their technology and energy needs years ago. Overall, it was worthwhile watching. Just slow. Finally, with apologies to Judy Collins, "Send In the Clones".
summary: Pretty good Sci-Fi, but somewhat slow and derivative

reviewText: I apologize but find it necessary to comment on a film which will probably gross 4 hundred million dollars or more in "its " lifetime. I promise not to give any plot give aways but just read some Bradbury or Ellison and you are almost There.This film was more  than 120 minutes of so called entertainment and I will.probably never think about it again.The locations were wisely chosen but with many graphics added.Many film lovers like to go back and THINK about the film from time to time . Not all great films need that all important message but please let our minds run a little wild with imagination from time to time after viewing a block buster with a fine cast and new visions of the future.Think about a film such as SILENT RUNNING. You saw the near future with a cast of three humans  and two robots. We were given an actual view of the importance of inter species relationships.Humankind to nature.We saw and hopefully still think how reckless we have been  with land development and its long term impact on OUR planet.A film may leave us with hope and compassion such as ET. Its a classic .Much simpler sets .Its greatness is in the fantasy left for the audience to dream and wonder.In Oblivian its not there.This film is just another clone of deception which I see every day in our politics and marketing of new products. Oblivion does not churn any new thoughts for me. As I stated earlier its just 2 hours of entertainment and its gone. Please do not misuderstand me . Some films are just that ,pure entertainment. When it comes to the sci fi genre Im hoping for more. Lets rattle the cages ,stir up strong feeling we have for a brighter future or how to prevent global catastrophe. I did not get a whisper from this film . I watched this film three times wondering when am I going to get it (didnt finish round three and just gave up.No loss to the producers though . Much money and time spent with a great $ return. Why not it is Mr. excitement himself. He just missed this time . Please show me what I have missed. Is this a film from a graphic novel that was  just too subtle for me to get all the physical metaphors ?Truly, I know many films are a disappointment when you expect more of whatever. Grossing the national debt on a film that did not provide much in.entertainment or lacked  a thought provoking idea in anyway is sad.

reviewText: The story line is enjoyable, but it's the shots that make this movie shine. So many moments that are filmed beautifully, capturing the essence of the scene. Some interesting twists and I highly recommend watching it a second time after the first once you know the ending so you can look for clues in the movie you may have missed the first time through. Overall I enjoy this and own it now so I can re-watch it - missing some of the depth I'd like to see from a 5-star movie but again the fact it is enjoyable, has great action sequences but overall just a pleasure to watch warrants 4 stars for sure.
