reviewText: There may be spoilers.Some critics have panned this new film from director and co-writer Joseph Kosinski, in this his second film ("TRON: Legacy"), as being highly derivative.  But let's face it, how many films are so fresh and new that they delve into uncharted territory?  In any case, don't care.  Whether it's a drama, a comedy, a horror movie or even a romantic comedy, it's how well it is delivered that counts.  And this film delivers.Like "TRON" the film is visually arresting.  Seen on a big screen, the sets are huge but sparse, drawing the audience in.  Set in a war-ravaged Earth of 2077 devoid of humans, all of whom have resettled on a moon of Saturn, only Jack (terrific Tom Cruise) and Victoria (Andrea Riseborough) remain.  They are partners (both romantic and professionally) whose mission is to watch over the drones that patrol the area for a smattering of "Scavs" who were the defeated invaders.  While Earth won the war, they lost the planet which continues to be harvested for water and other ecological matter.Jack is the investigative repair man who goes out alone.  Victoria never leaves their high control point and guides him using sophisticated tracking technology.  While investigating an unusual radio beacon, Jack witnesses a spacecraft crash.  One of the survivors is a human flight officer named Julia (Olga Kurylenko) who he has occasionally dreamed about.  Both Jack and Vic have had their memories "washed" in order to eliminate thoughts of the terrible war.  Uh, sure.  What Jack believes to be "Scavs" turns out to be Beech (Morgan Freeman) and his collection of survivors.  The truth is out there and Jack must find it, and does with the help of Julia.Like "TRON,"  "Oblivion" is beautiful to watch and has a great soundtrack, mostly provided by French electronic band, M83.  Yes, "Oblivion" borrows from a list of movies too long to mention, but for those of us who salivate for science fiction films with a breath of intelligence, this one does the trick.BLU RAY REVIEW: In this subsequent viewing of this terrific sci-fi film, I was able to tie up a few elements I didn't quite understand the first time around.  I would also have to say this is one of the best looking movies of any genre I've seen.  The special features on the Blu ray disc add some clarity on how and why the filmmakers went for a certain look and it truly comes across beautifully.The other thing I had missed the first time around was the romantic relationship between Jack and Victoria and subsequently Julia.  It was there but just wasn't a point of focus.  By "there," I mean it wasn't explicit, either by subdued actions or love making.  Regarding the later, the most interesting coupling occurs in the swimming pool.  It seems clear that Jack's relationship with Victoria seems forced or maybe expected is a better word.  He does all the right things that husbands and wives do, but it seems like a matter of routine more than true love.  Watch Cruise's face during those intimate close ups.  Something is wrong.  Of course those memory flashbacks of Julia don't help.  When Jack finally does find Julia, it all clicks.  Not quickly, but you can see in Jack's reactions, he loves this woman.  But why?  In the end, he shows how much he loves her.  "Oblivion" is also a beautiful love story.There is nothing like watching a beautiful movie like this on the big screen, but this Blu Ray transfer comes damn close.  The 1080p transfer is spectacular in every respect and certainly will be a show off piece to a good system.  It comes in the original aspect ratio of 2.39:1 and does a great job replicating the original film.  The dystopian world is now essentially uninhabited and the stark whites and various shades contrast nicely with deep dark blacks.  When the story moves underground, shadows and shadings of grey prevail.  But even when Jack retreats to his cabin in the wilderness, we get beautiful greens and various earth tones in all their splendor.  I could see no encoding issues.  The contrast and detail are excellent.Equaling the visuals is a magnificent DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1 audio track.  Again put this one on your demo list.  If you have sub-woofers, they will get a workout as the rumbles coming from many sources including gunfire, rockets and explosions.  The surrounds are constantly in play with movement from side to side, back and forth as the drone ships fly around.  Dialog is clear and well presented.  Ambient noise is ever present as well.Extras include an excellent commentary track by Tom Cruise and director Joseph Kosinski, a 48 minute "making of" documentary, some deleted scenes and get this, an isolated musical score by M83 in Dolby TruHD 5.1 (24 bit, 96kHz).  A great package to own.
summary: (BLU RAY UPDATE) 4 1/2 stars for a visually arresting sci-fi beauty

reviewText: This film was way better than I expected going in. It features some of the best visual effects I have seen in a long time, but it doesn't sacrifice character development or a good story in the process. Oblivion feels like a much more complete movie than the director's last effort, Tron: Legacy, which was pretty much just eye candy. The musical score is also a thing of beauty. I need this soundtrack!I may not like Tom Cruise the person, but he can more than hold his own on screen. Morgan Freeman is always good, even in a tiny role like this. The two female leads are easy on the eyes with Andrea Riseborough turning in a memorable performance as Jack's (Tom Cruise) mission partner/lover and Olga is well...easy on the eyes.The story does get a little confusing from time to time and some of the twists were a bit obvious (at least to me), but by the end I pretty much had it all figured out. I will surely be adding this one to my blu-ray collection.

reviewText: Sci-fi that involves Cruise or Travolta can be suspicious at times, but I thought this movie was worth watching.  I paid full price to get it here on AMZ, but it's better than sitting in a theater with noisy dolts.  The non-main characters are flat and quiet, but at 2 hours, there wasn't much time to get other characters yapping as well.I love disaster movies and often think that earth would be better off without us, some of what I saw in this film reminded me of personal ideas and it's nice to see them out there in parallel.  Some reviews said that this movie was confusing and it had me wondering if the movie critic had any good brain cells left. If you want confusing double up on Inception and 12 Monkeys. Oblivion is fine, but it's not Memento or Butterfly Effect for worthy plot twists.Don't look for a super tight story line, and I'm sure you'll find the same holes in the story that I did.  Some things can be explained if you just fill in the blanks yourself. For instance the life pod that gets reused for Julia, says "Harper" on the lid. They got it by going back to a site to reuse it. I'm leaving out the spoiler bits, but you get it. If you pay attention or watch it a few times, you'll fill in the questions. MM
summary: It's not confusing, and worth watching.

reviewText: Minor Spoilers through out:One of the biggest complaints is that "Oblivion" borrows a lot from other movies. It's true, but a rather hypocritical reason to trash a movie when in fact just about every sci fi movie has been significantly influenced by its predecessors. The fact that it borrowed from other movies didn't bother me- "Oblivion" still has its own voice and unique look.For all the critics who declare "Oblivion" is superficial, all style and no substance, I couldn't disagree more. "Oblivion" is an intelligent, symbolic and gorgeously filmed story. Like most intelligent sci fi, "Oblivion" explores age old philosophical questions of the human condition- do we have souls, do we have free will or are our fates predestined, etc.One of the major themes of Oblivion is that the voices of authority may not be as benevolent and as trustworthy as we' like to believe, and that individual thought and scrutiny are crucial to preserving freedom and humanity. The TET is a physical manifestation / representation of that power that influences us: religion, politics, the mass media - depending on how you look at it.Meanwhile, Jack and Victoria portray different ends of the power struggle: where he is eager, wants answers to the unknown, and is open to exploring new paths and breaking free from the chains that bind him, she is more concerned with doing what she is told, not rocking the boat, and sticking to the path that is set out before her without question or deviation. You could even take it a step futher and ask whether Jack and Victoria are merely acting the way they were MADE to act, or if they CHOOSE to act the way they do (the free will vs. predestination aspect). There is much beyond the surface story to enjoy and ponder on, for those who like that kind of thing. I can't wait to listen to the commentary for additional information.Also this movie is very pleasant on the eyes and ears. One of the most stunning HD movies I've seen to date, with a beautiful musical score by M83 to match. The entire film, from story to soundtrack to visual f/x, all pulls together like an eloquent poem, something that few films successfully manage to achieve. Movies like Oblivion certainly won't be liked by everybody, and not everyone will see the "eloquent poem" that I saw: Some of my friends were as disenchanted with it as much as I was mesmerized by it. As for me, I think it's one of the better pure sci fi films I've seen in awhile.
summary: Fantastic Cerebral Sci Fi  With Heavy Themes

reviewText: An Earth laid waste, debris and dust al around with one lone technician doing what he can to keep things running.  No, not Wall*E, but Tom Cruise as Jack (Tech 49) repairing the drones left behind to protect giant energy convertors, all that is left of use on Earth.  In this, Tech-49 is aided by Andrea Riseborough in their austere home in the clouds.  At the start of the movie, Jack is clearly more philosophical troubled by what they do than she is, but this is overshadowed by a greater disturbance in their routine when Jack finds a survivor, played by Olga Kurylenko, which forces Jack to reassess all he knows about his mission.First off, the design is just fantastic.. it's a beautifully detailed world, a believably scorched earth in contrast with their sleek minimalist modern living environment.  It's clear that throw cushions and terracotta are not in fashion in the future.  Also, the director Joseph Kosinski (Tron: Legacy (Two-Disc Blu-ray/DVD Combo)) has once again used a contemporary soundtrack which manages to be both epic and modern adding an energy to the movie that it might not have had with a more conventional symphonic score.Tom Cruise never quite escapes being Tom Cruise, making it hard for us to invest in his character, but Andrea Riseborough more than makes up for it with a character so buttoned up that her expressions of emotion need only be the slightest of moments to make a great impact - it's a great performance.  Kurylenko never feels quite at home in her role here, but passes muster.  Morgan Freeman - well, who can say that watching Morgan freeman isn't a pleasure, but he is hardly stretched in what turns out to be quite a minor role.  Great entrance though, which focusses on his distinctive voice before he is revealed in person.  At the end of that short monologue, Freeman says `Lights' and the greater picture is revealed... and that sort of sums up the direction.  After every moment of characterisation, we swiftly move past to reach a reveal of some greater plot or art design, which sort of shows you where the director's heart really is.  He's more interested in the big ideas, than where his characters are coming from or going to.  Many of those ideas in the movie are not original - you get the feeling in the movie frequently of `Oh, that's just like in the movie `insert movie here'.. (it would be churlish to name the movie references and spoil the fun of finding them for yourself).  However, it's been put together in such a stylish way and with such conviction from the director, that it's a success.  Ultimately it's good to see stylish thoughtful sci-fi gracing the big screen, and I for one give it a thumbs up.

reviewText: I'll be upfront and admit I'm not crazy about Tom Cruise.  In fact, I really don't like him very much because he seems to full of himself in movies.  So naturally when I saw him in this sci-fi looking film, I turned against it right away.Still, I was a bit bored and wished to go to the movies (yes, I love the popcorn there), so I gathered two friends and went thinking they will probably love it more than me.By the end of the film, my friends and I politely clapped!  I was pleasantly surprised and will buy the blu ray when it comes out.I will not discuss what it is about for fear of spoiling it, but I do encourage to go and see it with an open mind and not to pay attention to those who have reviewed this negatively.I heard that it's predicable, shallow, dull and nothing surprising.  I do disagree on all counts and found it very entertaining.Hey, at least it's better than Star Wars 1, 2 or 3 and a 100 times better than Prometheus (which was the most disappointing film I've ever seen and I loved Alien & Aliens).And at last I actually liked Tom Cruise.  Of course Morgan Freeman is always good, so no problems there.Just don't try and guess what happens next in the film.  Just let it happen and enjoy it (with popcorn).

reviewText: Just because I don't like Tom Cruise. No.I like Tom Cruise. He's a yeoman. Good.Still, crap movie. Over two hours of anyone's life sucked. If. They watched this movie all the way through. I did. And I learned a lot. Though I was sucked. Rudely. Sucked. Dare I say I paid for it, too? Four or five dollars. That I'll never have to spend again on something...else.First of all, why are they still paying Tom Cruise to do anything in the category of suspense? If Tom Cruise is in it, you know it's going to end well for him whether he lives to die another day, or, as in the case of this movie, not. He's either a hero or a Saint. Comforting, if that's what you're into.Then there was that whole stultifying middle part of the movie where there were (not just one but) two Tom Cruises. Wearing the same poorly designed costume. (and for this I had to wait two extra weeks 'til I could afford to watch how badly Tom Cruise would embarrass himself this time? why?)I like Tome Cruise, but Tom Cruise is a bad actor. He sells tickets but, he's a bad actor. As an actor he doesn't know his limits (which is good), but he doesn't know what he's good at, either (which is not good).In Oblivion he's taken on a story that requires stopping first; Cruise plunges ahead. Hold still, even if all he's got is a second, before firing. Know how to stop and hold still; Cruise can't.Still, good for him for considering the possibility. Likewise, in his next movie, I hope he'll consider looking his age.Ambitious movie. Over two hours. Beautiful design. But Tom Cruise was the bad actor at the center of it. So, one star for the design, one for doing a hard tell. Other wise three stars down on account of Tom Cruise is a bad actor.

reviewText: Earth has suffered a cataclysmic alien attack. In an effort to save the human race and the planet, we fight back. Nuclear weapons are deployed. We fight valiently but it is not enough. The population is decimated. Cities are destroyed. The Earth is in ruin, virtually uninhabitable. The survivors are left with no other choice but to flee the dying planet and make a new home on Titan, Saturn's largest moon.Now imagine that you are one of the only people left on Earth, tasked with protecting and syphoning what few resources remain so that your people can survive. This is Jack Harper's (Tom Cruise) job. He and his partner, Victoria (Andrea Riseborough), are tasked with drone maintanence --- drones that are critical for protecting their harvest operations. These drones are the last line of defense from hostile "Skav" attacks. The pair's mission commander, Sally (Melissa Leo), provides support from the space colony above. In a few short weeks, the harvesters will have collected enough of the remaining raw material needed to ensure humanity's long-term survival and Jack and Victoria can then return to be with their people. Only, after a drone repair goes horribly wrong, Jack is left questioning the motives behind his mission and the supposed dangers posed by the Skavs. And he quickly learns, things on the surface are not what they seem.when I saw the trailer for Oblivion coupled with the knowledge that Joseph Kosinski (of Tron: Legacy fame) was attached to direct, I was super excited. So I may not be the biggest Tom Cruise fan or anything but with an all-star cast consisting of Melissa Leo, Morgan Freeman and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau (aka Jamie Lannister from FREAKING Game of Thones!!!), there was no way this movie wasn't going to be a sure-fire winner. To sum up, Oblivion has everything you want/expect out of the genre: killer SFX, action aplenty, pivotal plot-twists and aliens (of course); but it also delivers more than what you initially anticipated. You go into it expecting spaceships and lasers and invasions but you come out having seen so much more.I will utter a word of caution, however, to those of you who expect to watch your a-typical sci-fi thriller: you will probably walk away from Oblivion feeling slightly underwhelmed because the movie takes its time while unraveling its mysteries. It doesn't just jump straight into the action like many others do these days. But if you love a good storyline, I think you'll be thoroughly pleased with what you see. I have to give Kosinski credit for doing the impossible --- he finds that all-important balance between showing riveting action on screen and telling a captivating story, especially in a genre where excessiveness reigns supreme. This isn't just another alien invasion story. There's some good stuff here. And while even the most adamant of sci-fi fans might preemptively anticipate several of said plot twists, it never detracts from the intended impact.But as much as I hail this movie for its amazingness, it's not without its flaws either. There was one big thing that forced me to knock my glowing review down from a 5-star to a 4-star rating. Oblivion isn't just a sci-fi film, oh no. It's a stupid love story! When you expect aliens, instead you get a googly-eyed, sap-filled romance. In fact, a good chunk of the film is dedicated to this unanticipated plotline and it made me absolutely crazy! It's kinda similar to what I felt for the movie Titanic. If you take out the love stuff, the movie would've been so much better! Look, I know what you're thinking. It's not that I'm anti-love, I'm just not a fan of love where it doesn't belong ---- like on sinking ships and in goddamn alien invasions! Get with the program people! When it comes to, I dunno, my survival or getting in my kicks one last time, you bet I'm gonna go with the former.So, yeah. The love stuff. Not a big fan. And that brings me to Olga Kurylenko. Where I felt like Riseborough owned her performance (even the romantic parts), Kurylenko's character only serves to move the love story forward. And while she's not terrible, she's not exactly pivotal either --- more like, just another pretty face. Her character, while it does add some momentum to the spacey stuff, doesn't really inspire. The big surprise for me was Tom Cruise. As I said before, I'm not exactly Tom's biggest fan. For me, he plays much the same character in every movie he's in --- the more-than-meets-the-eye-bad-ass on a mission who ends up questioning authority.That's essentially the case here, only there's more of a softness behind his performance than I've seen in recent years. And where Cruise can sometimes seem a bit alien in real life, he's shockingly human in Oblivion. He proabaly won't win any awards for this performance but you do have to appreciate those subtle nuances that cause you to sympathize with his character's plight. Another suprise for me was how little screen time Melissa Leo and Morgan Freeman are given. Their roles albeit miniscule, do serve a larger, more all-encompassing purpose though. They each serve as a meaningful addition and do shine with whatever time they're alloted. I won't say much for Nikolaj Coster-Waldau's character other than HUBBA-HUBBA!Another amazingly effective role in the film was actually played by the drones. They are surprisingly animated, each reflecting distinctive and very quirky personalities. They kind of reminded me of WALL-E, in a more deadly shoot-em-up, kind of way. They served to highlight the terrifying nature of Earth's precarious situation and to bring the comedy needed to lighten the mood. And to this I tip my hat to the SFX guru's behind-the-scenes. Much of the drones' character was emphasized by the incredible realness of the barren landscape and the stark modernness of their technology. It also doesn't hurt that I saw the movie in IMAX so much more attention to detail is paid visually as well as audibly. I'd say that I had some fairly high expectations for this film, most of which were met. Oblivion is wrought with surprises mostly good, some bad, but overall, I was pretty blown away by its depth and the post-apocalyptic journey on which we went.Food for Thought: Oblivion is a surprisingly contemplative film with genre-defying cinematography. For a flawed film, strong performances, unexpected plot twists and appropriately timed action make it a must-see. And despite complaints that I might have, both fans and non-fans of the genre can find something to enjoy whether it be the sci-fi journey or the romance that drives it making this movie a sure bet for all!

reviewText: I can't remember how long it has been since I have seen a classic sci-fi movie. All the recent entries in the genre have been either superhero movies or bombastic-boom-boom-shoot-em-up-alien-invasion ones. And while Oblivion does tread familiar ground sometimes it gets 5 stars by comparison with its peers in the industry at the moment. On its own, it is technically superb with a great sweeping soundtrack, well presented minimalist art direction, stunning landscapes, great acting from a small and excellent cast and tight screenplay that keeps your attention (if you have been longing from a reprieve of movies with giant ball of fires every 2 minutes). This movie also manages to stand on its own without the need for sequels which probably means it gets another 5 stars just for that.From the end credits, it seems that it has been adapted from an unpublished graphic novel and the writer of said novel directs this movie so I guess I saw his vision of his book. And it's only after I came here that I realized that he directed TRON Legacy too (another excellent movie). Hats off to Joseph Kosinski.Whatever you think about Tom Cruise, he sure as heck can deliver a great action/sci-fi movie. This one revolves around him and he carries it effortlessly while displaying a wide variety of emotions ever so subtly. His supporting cast is very good in general but I thought that Andrea Risenborough displayed a wider set of emotions really well and it probably would have been better if she and Olga Kurylenko had switched roles. Morgan Freeman, Coster-Waldau and Leo deliver excellent performances with the little screen time they have and to be honest I really like movies where the director manages to make a story around a small set of characters work well.This is a very good sci-fi movie. If you have ever read sci-fi short stories (Dick, Asimov etc.) and ever wondered how it would be on film, this would be a good example.

reviewText: When I first saw a trailer for Oblivion, I felt like it was custom made for me. Then, last night, while watching it in IMAX,they started playing a Led Zeppelin song in the movie, I knew it was made for me. Oblivion was a mix of the greatest Sci-Fi already made and yet it was still unique in its own way. Other reviewers have said that the writing is better in the first half and that the movie becomes predictable or not as strong in the second half. I completely disagree. I felt like the script, while borrowing bits from other Sci-Fi, remained engaging and well-done through out the whole movie. If you see this movie in IMAX, in addition to being blown away by the incredible surround sound, you will actually see more of the picture than in a traditional theater. They opened it up for most of the movie. There were a few parts (only one I noticed was around the beginning) where it was the more narrow widescreen picture. For the rest of the time it filled up the huge IMAX screen. The special effects, details, set design, sound design, music, and acting were all top notch in Oblivion (well, Olga was about as good as you can expect from her). The best part about this movie was that my wife liked it. She said it didn't stress her out too much. She also loved the way the music went with the movie. She thought the surround sound and sound effects were some of the best she's heard in a long time. She said she wants to see it again just for the sound. I highly recommend this movie. I liked how by the end, all loose ends are tied up and everything makes sense. This movie does give you the opportunity to think deeper on the meaning, or you can just take what they give you and be totally fine. Go see it in IMAX. I wonder when Tom Cruise will start looking his age...? A note on the CONTENT of the PG-13 rating: Sci-Fi violence on a Star Wars level of graphic-ness. Language that is Low to Middle of the road for PG-13. There is 1 "F" word, as is normal for PG-13 now-a-days, and a few "S" words and "SOBs." Religious exclamations were very minimal, like two I think. There is a pool scene where you see a dark silhouette of rear female nudity then you can see it through the water for a short time also. In another scene, we see a bare female back from the waist up. Thanks for reading, now go watch this in IMAX. Go in with an open mind and be ready to have fun!BLU-RAY UPDATE: I'll keep this brief. The picture and sound are PERFECT. The only downside is that the blu-ray does NOT include the IMAX aspect ratio change, it stays in 2.39:1 the whole time. The special features are actually really satisfying. And it doesn't take that long to get through them. If you want to see how any aspect of this movie was made, you will see in the making-of portion. If you are like my wife, and feel that the behind the scenes stuff ruins movies, then don't watch this part, because it definitely uncovers the magic behind key scenes. The Audio commentary with the Director and Tom Cruise was extremely interesting and entertaining. The musical score isolated audio track was actually really engaging and showed off the beautiful score. The deleted scenes added a bit of depth. Overall, it is a fantastic blu-ray of an awesome movie. This movie holds up to repeat viewings because you'll notice new stuff each time. Enjoy!

reviewText: Epic, slick, and at times a little lost, OBLIVION is a well meaning scifi flick that takes too many wrong turns telling it's tale.Part MATRIX, part TOTAL RECALL, director Joseph Kosinski's tale of a future earth destroyed by alien attack (aided in part by their destruction of the moon).  In the very first minute of the film we're told in a voice over that while humanity won the war (by using nukes), the planet is now a barely recognizable radioactive wasteland.  The few people left are essentially mechanics for huge water processing plants meant to help reestablish humanity on the moon Titan.Tom Cruise's character is plagued by strange dreams of earth before the invasion - an earth he never saw.  These dreams are apparently brought on by the mind wipe he must go through to ensure that if captured by aliens, he can reveal no vital information.  Otherwise he seems content in fixing battle robots meant to destroy the few remaining alien stragglers and having loveless sex with his outpost partner.So much of this film's strategy is based on a slow reveal of a great secret.  Without getting in to details, it's a form of storytelling I've been been overly fond of - the flashback.  While it basically works (there's no doubt that all's not as it should be, right from the start), I can't help but wonder what might have been if this film was told as a linear narrative.And that's because Cruise is never really able to emotionally attach to anything or anyone in the movie, despite a mighty effort to do so.  The story is told in such a disjointed way that one spends more time trying to figure out what the mystery is as opposed to really caring what happens to the people in the story.Now if the script were more witty in it's dialogue or if the music was better, perhaps this style of film making would have worked better.  But the script is as plain a white bread - absolutely bland and perfunctory.  The music is worse - while electronic band M83 (Anthony Gonzalez & Joseph Trapanese) strive for something grand & epic, it comes off a bland version of Daft Punk's TRON: LEGACY score.  That's ironic as Kosinski also directed that otherwise very bland film.  OBLIVION absolutely screams out for a classical score like John Barry might have done, or something as far out and passionate as Vangelis, but instead is as generic as you're likely to hear in a major movie.Put simply, there's very little heart or soul in this film.  The effects are clean, crisp, and largely excellent, and the acting - while not stellar - is certainly good enough.  As are the sets, costumes and the like.  In the end Kosinski seemed far too occupied with the twists of the road as opposed to why he's on it in the first place.  That coupled with bland lines and music really helps limit what could have been a much more thrilling film.  One other huge negative - there's really only about an hour's worth of story here (at least as Kosinski tells it), yet OBLIVION is over two hours long, and that is the kiss of death for me.BOTTOM LINE:  3 "They blew up the moon in VAMPIRELAND too!" stars out of 5
summary: A slick but mostly souless scifi romp

reviewText: I'm a Sci-Fi fan and and this movie is great. If you are used to sci fi in general you'll probably figure out the huge plot point within a couple of minutes of the movie starting, but you'll still have to continue watching to understand why that is the case.This isn't your standard post apocalyptic alien invasion movie. It has a little bit more brains. The setting is fantastic, the environment and cinematography is fantastic. Acting is ok, action is great, and the over arching plot point, really sets it apart from your standard "Aliens invade en mass and try to kill us." There is a far more intelligent methodology. What makes it work is the perspective that the move is told from. Meaning Tom Cruises characters's perspective is a unique take on a classic theme. Give it a shot.

reviewText: I read a few of the reviews before watching this movie, and I almost did not watch it. I am glad I did. I read that the plot did not make sense. I think the plot makes perfect sense, and is interesting as well as ingenious as well as sweet. I will make one small criticism: the perfect home and machines that the 2 humans live and work in seem too perfect to be true ( but I think that the alien tech entity could easily maintain them ) Another small complaint: we are supposed to believe that this fantastic technological entity still needs humans to repair some of the machines ( I believe that this is probable, just look at our own world, machines are always breaking down ). And one other small criticism: We only see one small group of survivors ( actually, I prefer this. Some movies, like the matrix, try to show too much and thereby become less interesting ). So you see that all my criticisms actually are not criticisms at all. This story is solid, well told, moves along swiftly, and is continually interesting. Even the schmaltzy parts are perfect. There is one small but important scene which cries out for the perfect soundtrack song. I found myself thinking that this would be the perfect place to play A Whiter Shade Of Pale... and it plays!!!! The inevitable ending has two ( TWO ) surprises that actually took me by surprise. I felt warm and happy and satisfied.
summary: a classy, gorgeous,snazzy, emotional science fiction story

reviewText: We see a lonely sky-castle resting up in the clouds, and a beautiful couple preparing to go to Titan as the Earth is laid waste by aliens who have destroyed the Moon. Reminiscent of  Sonmi episode of Cloud Atlas, this Tom Cruise starer is exhilarating, lyrical as the camera travels through undulating Icelandic scenery in this never-seen before cinematography. reviewText: I rented this since I am a Cruise fan and pretty much see all his stuff automatically. After viewing it, I bought the blu-ray--I knew I would want to see it several more times. While I actually liked the story, I was particularly drawn to all the sets--the house in the sky, the pool, the earth landscape, the cool plane he flies, even the drones. I found it easy to become immersed in that world....which made the actual story less important. Watching the extra features greatly enhanced my enjoyment as well. A LOT of work went into making this movie look the way it does. Five stars all around from me.Edited to add: I notice that a lot of reviews are complaining that it was too digitized and too many special effects. How ironic that the producers would go to such lengths for realism (as shown in the extra features).....and they were so successful that the assumption is that it's all fake! The vast barren earth scenes are real, shot in Iceland. The scenes out the windows of the sky house are actual photographs of clouds and sunrise/set, projected onto a 360-degree screen surrounding the house (no blue or green screens). Surprisingly little of this film was CGI.

reviewText: After seeing this movie in the theater, it instantly became one of my all time favorites.  I have watched it about another dozen times on Cinemax since, and will be purchasing the DVD as well.  I am a Tom Cruise fan, a sci-fi fan, and especially a post-apocalyptic sci-fi fan, but this movie stands on its own merits in just about every other regard as well.  It has a great supporting cast, phenomenal visual effects and soundtrack, intelligent storyline, plot twists, and much more.  The only [slight] disappointment I have is that I would have liked to see a little more character development and screen time with Morgan Freeman's character.This movie is smart, intriguing, and draws you right into the plot and scenery.  I don't feel it rips-off concepts from other sci-fi films, rather pays homage, as the writers were going for.  The concept of the enemy faced by humanity is great (I won't give away any spoilers).  This said, if you are looking for a shoot-em-up, fast paced, action packed journey through the cosmos, then this isn't for you.  If you want a great story that makes you think and gives you some surprises, all the while dazzling you with great effects and scenery, as well as music, then this is for you.  Let's put it this way...this movie has much more in common, in terms of plot and action, with old-school Star Trek then the new Trek movies...in other words it's a thinker and a mystery with a sci-fi tone, rather than a shoot-em-up action ride.  I loved it...5 out of 5 stars and easily in my top 10 sci-fi features of all time.

reviewText: The borrowing of themes and memes from other sci-fi movies can't be ignored. Thus deduct a star for lack of originality. But the special effects and beautiful cinematography are (to use a cliché) truly visually arresting. (That it's not completely CGI makes a huge difference. Are you reading this, Mr. Lucas?) The acting is actually really good. (Cruise gives a great, nuanced performance ... for once.) I regret missing seeing this in the movie theaters or Imax. The "extras" in the Blue Ray are not overwhelming. But they are interesting. It's not clear why the deleted scenes were deleted. They all should have been left in. If you can overlook the borrowed thematic elements then you will love this movie.P.S. Almost forgot -- the sound track by M83 is fantastic. It adds to the overall quality of this movie. I've got it play-listed on my Spotify account. I have actually been listening to it all summer since it came out.
summary: The beauty of this movie compensates for its borrowing of themes and memes.

reviewText: Say what you will about Tom Cruise - and of his off-screen persona, most of what I'd have to say would be negative - but he is a great actor, who almost always delivers; and this is one of his best performances. This is a thinking man's science fiction flick...not only is it visually stunning with some nifty CGI special effects, it also has an intelligently written script, with dialogue that is ofttimes poetic, as the opening quote exemplifies. Set in 2077, 60 years after Earth is invaded by alien beings called Scavengers (Scavs), who destroy the Moon, resulting in a tectonic upheaval, that - combined with nuclear weapons, used to defeat the aliens, have resulted in Earth becoming virtually uninhabitable. The remaining humans inhabit a huge space station and have established a colony on Titan, one of the moons of Saturn. Cruise as Jack Harper, is Tech 49, who is responsible for patrolling the radiation-free sections of Earth and for maintenance of drone warships that hunt down the remaining Scavs. He is assisted by his communications officer and lover, Victoria (Andrea Riseborough). At the end of one of his patrols, the Odyssey, a NASA spaceship crashes and in the only survivor is a mysterious female, Julia (Olga Kurylenko). But things are not exactly as they seem. Be prepared for some surprises, beginning with the appearance Julia and Malcolm Beech (Morgan Freeman) who leads an underground stronghold of...humans. Produced, directed and written by Joseph Kosinski, he gets triple credit for its excellence. If you love the genre as much as I do, you will love this outstanding sci/fi flick.
summary: "Is it possible to miss a place you've never been? To mourn a time you never lived?"

reviewText: I don't expect much from movies nowadays, as most movies rely on CG and explosions to make it worthy of your time and money. reviewText: I almost didn't get this movie, because the critics tore it apart.  However, after reading the reviews on Amazon, I decided to buy it.  I am glad I did.Everyone agrees that this movie is visually stunning.  It is, but let's get past that.  Right off the bat, you are made to think about what is happening.  You have the strange feeling that something isn't quite what it appears, but you don't know what.  Funny, but that is exactly the feeling of Tom Cruise's character.  Throughout the movie, it takes twists and turns that you didn't expect.The video and audio are excellent.  The casting was great.  Look, if you need a guy with an intense stare that doesn't quite know what is going on, Tom Cruise is perfect.  If you need someone to project that he really does know what is going on, Morgan Freeman is the natural choice.  The rest of the cast Was excellent, each portraying their characters to a tee.  Special credit to Melissa Leo for adding some incipient creepiness which was fun to watch.Now, why did I ignore all those one-star reviews?  First, those who said the movie was bad because they didn't understand it, put the blame in the wrong place.  Second, those who cried, "bad science", need to understand that the movie is entertainment, not education.  Sure, hydrogen is the most available element in the universe, but that does not prevent some visually interesting ways of obtaining it.  Yes, the story borrowed from other works.  The final destruction of the orbiting platform was straight out of ID4, but it made sense in the context of this movie, and that is what really matters.

reviewText: OBLIVION is a gorgeous movie to look at.  It's a marvel of brown and gray.  Tom Cruise is a charismatic movie star.  Those two elements alone make the film worth seeing.  And it's a good thing OBLIVION has those things going for it, because much of the rest is so-so at best.I appreciated the steady , slow-paced build of this film...it is not very action heavy, short of one extended (and disjointed) shootout in an underground bunker facility.  We really mostly spend A LOT of time in closeup with Tom Cruise, with a gorgeously ravaged earth all around him.We meet Cruise as he's setting out on another "drone repair" mission to earth...and earth that was essentially obliterated during a war with alien invaders.  We won the war, but had to abandon the ruined planet.  Cruise and his partner/lover (Andrea Riseborough) are all alone on a station build well above the surface of the planet.  Below, the cities and farmlands are all covered in dunes.  The top of the Empire State Building is all that pokes through the surface...most of the rest of NYC is buried.  Offshore, gigantic machines, serviced by drones, are pulling up the water from our oceans and are used up in a fusion process to bring energy to Saturn's moon, Titan...where the remnants of humanity have fled.Riseborough (an actress I don't know well, but who makes for an interesting, striking figure) stays on the station, while Cruise yearns to spend more and more time on earth.  He has no memories of the planet, but he has an infinite interest in what life was like there.  His passion for his work and for the planet are what draw us to his character.  Cruise is seldom a truly great actor.  But he's one of those stars (like Clooney) who are charismatic and engaging.  Cruise is usually helped by having a character with a dark side or a past...and we get hints of both.  He carries himself with both great physical assurance AND air of sadness.And the earth around him, bleak and nearly empty, is a CGI wonder.  I know that almost all of it is completely "fake" but the special effects teams have done a stellar job in creating a convincing, post-apocalyptic world that is lovely to look at.  I enjoyed the many scenes where Cruise flies around.  I'm so tired of bloated CGI worlds, be they Middle Earth or Thor's home planet or any other gilded, over-stuffed fantasy world.  OBLIVION feels "tasteful."  The color palette, from Riseborough's clothing to the hue of the sand dunes, is soothing and creative.Needless to say, the movie is not just about Cruise flying around earth.  Slowly and surely, the reality he thought he knew begins to come under assault, both from external factors and from bits of memory that come back to him.  I won't say more, because the movie wants you to slowly unravel its mysteries.  I won't spoil them, although I think they are not terribly inventive in the long run.  Eventually, other characters are introduced, and they are not well fleshed out, even for a sci-fi story.  Olga Kurylenko appears and I left to wonder again (as I did for QUANTUM OF SOLACE and HIT MAN) how she gets large movie roles.  She is bland and uninteresting.  Morgan Freeman is on hand, but does little more than talk like Freeman...it's barely a performance.I'll say again, it's a good thing the experienced and engaging Cruise is on hand to be our tour guide.  With a less compelling star, the less-original-than-its-creators-think plot and the mostly non-existent character development would doom this film.  As it is, I found enough here to like and to recommend the film.  I give it 3.5 stars, but will round up to 4.
summary: Gorgeous scenery, a charismatic Cruise and a so-so plot.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Oblivion(released April/13)stars,among others,Tom Cruise,Olga Kurylenko,Andrea Riseborough,Morgan Freeman and Nikolaj Coster-Waldau.Oblivion is certainly a different film,and Cruise is back doing what he does best;playing the intense,somber but conflicted role we know him to o so well.While he and co stars have a lot to say and do,the ultra long story has just far too much to tell,as it jumps from one narrative to another and back again.It unfortunately drags the film down and us with it.Speaking of which,we find ourselves in the year 2070.Earth is in total shambles and our hero is living high above the Earth with his female counterpart.They are singly manning the maintenance and security of the planet after its devastation involving a global conflict with aliens some 60 years before.There are gigantic water sucking machines that provide needed energy for the Earth colony on the moon of Titan,the largest of Saturn's moons.To aid the pair in their tasks are drones,round flying machines that help the pair cover the long distances involved in their jobs.They are monitored constantly from the "Tet",a gigantic space ship,which is the transition platform for those heading from Earth to Titan.In fact Cruise and his colleague are due to leave their posts in two weeks,barring any complications.Cruise has been bombarded for ages by memories of a woman he met on top of the Empire State building.One day they pick up a transmission coming from the top of that same building;the rest of which is buried deep beneath in the ground.He investigates to find out it has been deliberately programmed for transmission into space and for coordinates in a zone on Earth where there is no known life to speak of.Cruise cuts the signal,but shortly there after a space craft falls from the sky.Upon his arrival at the crash site he manages to rescue a woman from a stasis tube.A drone,also dispatched to the area from the Tet,kills the remaining survivors,much to his chagrin.The woman,as it turns out,is the self same one from Cruise's dreams.Cruise returns the tube to his habitat high above the Earth.They bring the woman back to life and interrogate her as best they can.Her main concern is getting the flight recorder from her crashed ship.Reluctantly Cruise takes her planet side and both get taken prisoners by Scavengers,or Scavs for short.It is these people that Cruise has been told were of alien origin and the ones that still sabotage their equipment.The Scavs however have a different story to tell.They are not of alien origin but human,and have been fighting the real aliens for years;the ones from the Tet who invaded Earth originally.They(the Scavs)want to send a destructive device into the Tet and blow it up,but they need Cruise to program a drone for them.When he refuses they send him and the woman he revived back into the wilderness to find answers in a radiation zone no one has been able to enter.Along the way the two stop at the Empire State Building again where the woman rekindles his memories further,only to find she is his wife.Cruise's partner has sent his ship back down to him and sees the two in an embrace.When Cruise returns to the habitat she refuses his entry and reports him to their superiors.This has the effect of unleashing a special drone underneath the habitat which first kills Cruise's colleague then turns on him.He is saved by his wife.The two flee but get pursued by three drones.Cruise manages to eliminate the three but not before he crash lands in the so called radiation zone.There his wife gets seriously wounded and  he finds out there are more caretakers like himself.In fact he witnesses one land and perform maintenance on a drone.It is in fact a clone of himself.While Cruise's official number is 49,this one's is 52.Cruise kills the clone,returns to the clone's habitat#52,greets his former colleague(obviously a clone also),and returns to Earth with a med kit to help save his wife's life.Armed with this new knowledge Cruise and his wife return to the Scavs and agree to help them defeat the aliens.Before they can get a programmed drone up and fling with the installed nuclear device,they are attacked by three more clones.Many people are killed,and its leader seriously wounded.The only option now is to take the bomb up to the Tet personally.Cruise puts his wife back into the stasis tube and blasts off to take her back to the Tet.Along the way he listens to the flight recorder which brings back more memories from his former life.Cruise now knows it was he who led the original expedition to Titan but was side tracked to investigate the Tet.Cruise ejected the stasis tubes on board before his ship was sucked into the Tet.The aliens then cloned Cruise and what would become his female colleague.The aliens sent thousands of Cruises to Earth to destroy the human population and left a few behind to tend to the planet destroying water devices.Cruise manages to enter the heart of the Tet.When he opens the stasis tube it is the leader of the Scavs.Both Cruise and he detonate the bomb together destroying the aliens.Fast forward two years and Cruises wife and their daughter are now living in a remote cabin on Earth Cruise had built prior to his death.Out of some brush across a lake arrives some Scavs and Cruise,but the numbered 52 clone,the one we thought Cruise had killed.It seems his memories had been awakened by Cruise#49 and his wife's presence and he had been searching for her ever since.There is much more to this plot,but as you can tell,it is long and very involved and we are taken back and forth,from one story to a back story,and back again and on and on.There are certainly some head scratching moments as when we get fooled by Freeman's presence in the Tet,and clone#52's appearance at the end as he"reunites" with his wife.Also when we view the back story and see Cruise eject the stasis tubes from his ship which is getting sucked into the Tet,we must ask:why wasn't the ejected section also sucked into the ship?Cruise has tried everything in his power to get out of the TET's grip and failed,but an ejecting part of the ship miraculously could break away of its own power? Hmmm.And there is also the question of clones,as in how many more were out there with latent memories of Cruises wife and when they came searching what would they do when they found their wife? Hmmmm.Questions,questions and more questions,with no answers.Or should I say a lot of plot holes that are quite deep?You decide.Technically speaking the film is clear and crisp in its original w/s a/r of 2:40:1.Extras include three featurettes,deleted scenes and commentary.All in all while a nice looking film,it is more style without substance.Its long and involved plot gets you clock watching part way through and wriggling in your seat.This film is unfotunately not the sum of its parts.Nice try,but no cigars.3 -3 1/2 stars.
summary: A long and involved story hampers this flicker!
Title: N/A

reviewText: A team of operatives are on an unlivable earth, wrecked by nuclear war after an alien invasion. They are tasked with maintaining the probes that seek out to kill the alien scavengers that are left. The remaining human population is on a space station away from the planet. reviewText: You'd think that producers would have realized by now that CGI does not guarantee a great film experience, that the basics of plot and character still count.  But no, we are continually dished up visual extravaganzas that have about as much originality as a 50s cowboy formula flick.This is a film about an outpost, run by Cruise and his girlfriend, which they believe is an outpost that will enable humans to colonize a moon and start over after a devastating war with a mysterious alien race.  The way that they live is fantastically vivid, as are the automated weapons that Cruise maintains to protect huge fusion reactors visible across the horizon.  It is a good life, but they are doing time, waiting to rejoin their cohorts on a space station.  Nonetheless, amidst his dangerous work routine, Cruise is disturbed by visions, seemingly old memories, of a girl he once loved, even though his memory has been "wiped" to protect information he purportedly has about the satellite.Things, it seems, are not what they appear.  And, of course, they turn out not to be.  On the positive side, the actors are good.  I am a Cruise fan, and Kurylenko and Morgan Freedman give strong performances, too.  I do not want to reveal the surprise explanation, and there are some nice twists, but really, once you have seen this you will not want to watch it over and over - there is not much to savor, beyond dazzling visuals and Cruise-style action.  Scratch beneath the surface, and you get next to nothing.I would only recommend renting this.  The fancy formats are fine, but why buy it for the rare viewing?

It didn't hold up quite as well, so mostly I use the Blu-Ray with the Isolated Score audio option it has.  It's a fantastic soundtrack, and I love to have it on in the background as I work.  I viewed a few of the other special features, but there's nothing particularly noteworthy here.

reviewText: I had no plans to follow through with this movie. Lately every movie I've been waiting to go to DVD has let me down. The previews rock my world only to find I can't sit through fifteen minutes. Grrh! Oblivion had a couple things going for it before I even pressed play. Science fiction and Tom Cruise. I live for end of the world survival drama and Tom's been one of my favorite actors since Legend.The movie starts off with a 12 Monkeys vibe because the opening scene is a glimpse of the past. Tell me you all saw that movie. It is one of the best of all time. The pacing is slow with long looks and minimal dialogue, but the tech is sleek and sexy. Everything is white or feels white, clean, even the ruins, but then darkness and unknowns are thrown in, which is the least flashy way a movie can create conflict and I loved it. Quiet spooky stuff. Then the music came into play, and I was thrown into a Terminator vibe. Very futuristic everyone is going to die via machine kind of way. I loved it! I was completely creeped out. Tom played one of his most subdued roles ever, almost funny at times. Morgan Freemen excels at that and he did here too. There's a mystery to be solved, humanity to save, and the last man on earth to get laid. Okay, Tom's not the last man on earth, but here he is getting some and the world has ended! That was a little too much, but at least it was very understated, which pays respect to how sci-fi movies should be. Except when it comes to the modern version of Battlestar Galatica. They had the best sex scenes.4.5 stars for Oblivion and I'm sure I'll watch it again because it's that cool. One more movie vibe reference. Wall-E. Weird, but let me know if you see what I'm saying here.

reviewText: It’s 2077. The Earth has been rendered virtually uninhabitable after an alien invasion that took place sixty-some years earlier. Even though the humans technically “won” the war (using nuclear weapons which pretty much wiped everything out), most of the planet’s survivors have long since moved to a colony on one of Saturn’s moons, leaving behind only a handful of people, like Tom Cruise’s Commander Jack Harper, as part of the “ mop-up crew,” whose job is to repair drones and to make sure the alien remnant known as the “scavengers” don’t interfere with the continued production of fusion power from the oceans that is needed by the humans living up on Titan.Complications arise when Jack rescues a female flight commander (Olga Kurylenko) whose vehicle is shot down by Scavs. Trouble is he thinks he may remember her from a time before he had his memory “swiped” as a needed security precaution given the sensitive nature of his job and mission.“Oblivion” is a visually elegant film from director Joseph Kosinski, adapted from his graphic novel, which was never published. The screenplay by Karl Gajdusek and Michael DeBruyn has some of the opaqueness of “Inception,” as, like a master card dealer, it shuffles the planes of reality to the point where the characters and the audience can’t quite make out what is actual and what is a mixture of dreams, memories and alternate realities. Similarly, the filmmakers seamlessly blend CGI action, metaphysics and a surprise, turnabout ending to create a subtle, thought-provoking vision of technology in a post-apocalyptic future.“Oblivion” takes its time telling its story, more concerned with mood and impression than with whiz bang action and plot details - though it doesn’t stint on either of those two things either.Andrea Riseborough, Melissa Leo and Morgan Freeman round out the cast, though Freeman’s character feels more plot contrivance than genuine person.“Oblivion” isn’t a completely satisfying movie in the final analysis, but its effective balance of tone and glorious visuals makes it worth watching.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Whenever Cruise's name is attached to anything like this, I automatically assume that it's crap, but this one turns out to be worth a look.  No doubt that whatever quality exists in Oblivion is due to the fact that director Joseph Kosinski was permitted to direct his own graphic-novel source material, and thus stay true to the sci-fi heart of the story.  I feel that discussing much of the plot very quickly gets into spoiler territory.  The set-up: Earth has been attacked by aliens, but humans have won the battle--at the cost of the Earth's habitability.  Remaining humans are being offloaded from the planet to a giant space station, while a few "techs" (Cruise) hunt down the last aliens (savages or "Savs").Special effects are more than acceptable for a current product.  The casting is successful:  Cruise doesn't repel;  Morgan Freeman is onscreen much, much less than his costar billing would tend to indicate.  Andrea Riseborough is notable as Cruise's "tech" assistant-lover.  And Olga Kurylenko has navigated the path from teenage model to talented movie actress suprisingly well; she's improved, bit-by-bit, in each movie she's appeared in recently.

reviewText: I have mixed emotions about this movie.  I was a little disappointed with it the first time I saw it, but watched it again several hours later and found that I appreciated it more and was able to ignore some of the holes in the plot (and it would be hard to describe them without giving away too much).  The main things are these:  It's handsomely, even spectacularly, made with an interesting premise, a lot of fascinating action between the characters, and a thoroughly satisfying resolution.  And I feel that those who rip this movie apart do so because it wasn't what they expected.  I hate to label it a thinking person's film, but to some degree it is, which is surprising, since it is based on a graphic novel and some of the action scenes seem straight out of a high tech video game.  But that's just a small part of it and most of the film revolves around intriguing characters. The director has created an amazing world here, with very good acting and some spectacular effects.  I went back and watched it a third time and liked it even more and intend to add the Blu-ray to my collection.  This is an excellent movie, and I just don't understand some of the hostility that has been directed towards it.  I think that it's a triumph for director Kosinsky and his wonderful crew.Follow-up: I did indeed buy it here on Blu-ray, and think of it as just short of 5 stars -- and I swear that my eyes fill with tears during the final moments every single time I've watched it! This is sci-fi with a heart, and a triumph for all involved in the making of it. Every time I see it, I like it more than I did the previous time! And I strongly recommend ALL the special features!

reviewText: I've admired Tom Cruise's work for years, his films are always well produced and entertaining. BUT OBLIVION is an aimlessly talky movie which seems purposeless and confusing, TC's acting is fine, though subdued. I wonder if shooting in Iceland froze his typical enthusiasm.Why did he agree to participate in such a pretty yet bland project?I have a theory: TC seems impulsive and on occasion a victim of his own raving enthusiasm. According to OBLIVION's 'Making of' Feature, TC was shown a graphic novel of Oblivion to illustrate the movie's potential/look and was blown away. And so signed on. The graphics he saw were indeed good. As great as the movie isn't. The 'Making of' feature has Cruise and company swooning over the design of eating utensils, chairs, costumes, imagined ships and stations. So, in a decorator haze he must've green-lighted the production. If he saw a script and read it, he must've been glowing in that initial haze, or he fell asleep.Oblivion's plot and Dialogue, in today's parlance, simply suck. Acting isnumb and occasionally dumb while the the entertainment quotient slurps.I saw another recent TC filmJack Reacher (Two-Disc Blu-ray/DVD Combo + Digital Copy). It's Great. Smart, sophisticated plot, dialogue, acting and action (TC's martial arts are especially real, good too; sure seemed he was the bad-guy thrasher, no stand-in as far as I saw). I gave it five stars, wishing more stars were allowed. I've seen it three times; (I'm retired from media; study production values. TC's JR film is fine the first time, even better in multiple viewings. See it, you'll see how well it's made...Circuitous + inane = Boring, frustrating and irritating. Pretty pictures though.I hope to find the graphic novel of OBLIVIOUS; er, sorry, OBLIVION.
summary: AFTER CONSIGNING$19.95 TO OBLIVION I VOW TO READ REVIEWS MORE CAREFULLY

reviewText: I think that I am finally all burned out on movies being made with an overwhelming wash of special effects and very little of what could be a story at all.The first 15 minutes of this film, I was really expecting it to be something great, but then this prolonged stretch of unwavering sameness just kept going on with very little of any kind of tangible story unfolding so, by about 45 minutes into the movie, I was getting really bored and didn't see or even expect it to improve and yet it wasn't even half way over yet.I think I saw it all.  I might have fell in and out of a sleep mode during the last half hour of the film so when it ended, I didn't even understand why it just ended right there. Maybe I missed something, and if I did, it's sad to think that if anything tied everything all together or made the story suddenly make sense, well, it must have been very short and easy to miss during a prolonged yawn or a blink.If I ever watch this movie again, I better have a double hit of some Red Bull so that I will be wired enough to not possibly fall asleep for at least a week. I'll wait about a month before I try this film again.  I bought it used, so I really gotta learn to be more selective when I take the risk of buying a movie I've never seen first.
summary: All special computer graphic effects, but no real interesting story at all

reviewText: Running time approx. 2 hr.  7.1 HD-DTS. This move gives subtle spoofs on Tom Cruises late movie (TOP GUN), and is a (half-baked) twisted modification of the late (2001 Space Odyssey). This movie is both stunning and disappointing at the same time. I think this movie could have been a huge hit, if it was more hardcore, bloody, and had strange creatures in it. Furthermore, the drab, dull and boring love story portrayed in this film did nothing for the movie, accept destroy it. Morgan Freeman is way too powerful of an actor to be in a movie like this. This is why his roll was short lived. Morgan Freeman practically cancelled out Tom Cruise, and seemed out of place in a movie like this. Overall, the cutting edge CGI effects in this movie were stunning! And the sci-fi (futuristic other worldly) panoramic sky, land, and sea scape's were also very stunning and brilliant. There are some dull, dry and boring areas in this movie; however its sheer sophistication will hold your attention. Based on the impact of the high quality production of this movie, I have to give it a solid (5) star rating, even though its really a disappointment in the end. The storyline has numerous holes, and leaves you with more questions than answers...in actuality the movie really doesn't make any sense at all, and will leave you scratching your head. However, for the sake of pure entertainment, its great. This movie has NO similarities to Star Wars, Tron, and Transfromers...at all! But you (WILL) see profound influences from 2001 Space Odyssey...I can promise you that. Those are the facts. Thank you.
summary: ***A twisted (spin) on the late 2001 Space Odyssey***

reviewText: [THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE THEATRICAL VERSION.]"Jack Harper: 60 years ago, Earth was attacked. We won the war, but they destroyed half the planet. Everyone's been evacuated. Nothing human remains. We're here for drone repair. We're the "mop-up crew".If you want to see a fun film with romance, excitement, plausible futuristic inventions, weaponry and computer-control, complete with Big Sister and the apparent salvation of the human race, watch this film.The film's beginnings concern an apocalypse of sorts, where in 2017 Man won, at a terrible cost, a war with an alien invasion. The remnants of that war, fought by the alien Scavs, want Jack (Tom Cruise) but not to kill him but to capture him.The cloud condo (I like to call it) has everything, complete with swimming facilities, showers, food and a hot red-headed, Brit-accented woman (Victoria) who also happens to be Jack's lover and communications officer.Every morning Jack goes out on patrol, fixes downed drones, and they complain to "management" up in "Tat", a large module miles wide, that is shuttling the last of humanity to its new colony on Saturn's moon, Titan.And every morning the communication from Tat asks , "Are you an effective team?" and all hell will break loose if it's other than "Yes!"Who could ask for more?There's more to the story than that. We are introduced to an apparency. And like Matrix, there is more than meets the eye and all is revealed, in bits and pieces, as the alien resistance, led by Morgan Freeman's character, Beech, is also not all it seems.Plots and Points:I won't reveal much, just to say the story will be familiar to many sci-fi fans. The action is non-stop (but it's not a military film), and the story slowly unfolds (but it's not Matrix). The plausible machinery (the dragonfly-like helicopter-ship with space travel capability) and Jack's cool, futuristic motorcycle are fun to watch and experience.The film's expostulation of what our world will be like is shocking - New York is completely wiped out. We have the library, subway system and the Brooklyn Bridge at hand. What sci-fi movie does NOT have the Statute of Liberty's arm up in the air, a common feature in these types of films since the Planet of the Apes!Best scenes: Getting your cycle stolen from aliens. I mean, that's really a shame! The humor as Jack catches that ball at the stadium, site of the 2017 World Series. And the hideaway that Jack keeps, a mountain lake and cabin, with remnants of humanity's technology (great Jazz vinyl) unknown to his partner Victoria.When a signal brings down Odyssey, a ship that's been in orbit "pre-War", and one survivor, a woman who had been in his flashback dreams, completely destroys all the harmony and substance of Jack's world and sends him on a frantic hunt to find the truth or meet elimination at the guns of drones!Bottom Line: If you like your sci-fi with great scenes, seamless CGI and a constant plot with no pausing, then see this film. The film does take some concentration and if you're observant, you can follow along just fine. In fact I may get the DVD to fill in any points I missed.IMAX, was worth it!Cast & Crew:Directed byJoseph KosinskiWriting creditsJoseph Kosinski (screenplay) andKarl Gajdusek (screenplay) andMichael Arndt (screenplay)CastTom Cruise ... JackMorgan Freeman ... BeechOlga Kurylenko ... JuliaAndrea Riseborough ... Victoria
summary: It's the End of the World As We Know It! Great Film!

reviewText: This flick is one GIANT cliché, with obvious, or should I say Oblivious, borrowing from past sci-fi flicks, many of them starring...TOM CRUISE!  I can always count on Tom Cruise 1.running fast 2.riding fast on a motorcycle. 3.fighting against the MAN and somehow winning in the end AND getting THE girl.The computer in his house on the table is from Minority Report, the helicopter in the canyon fighting drones is Star Wars Episode IV, His wife injured in the desert from The English Patient, the library scenes from War of the Worlds, sand people from Star Wars IV, Tom Cruise running fast from...well, every Tom Cruise movie ever starring Tom Cruise.Do we really need another (supposed) blockbuster film starring bigname actors such as Morgan Freeman and TOM CRUISE that succeed only in stuffing more cash in producers' and actors' pockets but leave the rest of us unwashed/moviewatchers wishing we had spent the evening shelling peas instead?

reviewText: Other than the GlaDOS-like super entity computer at the end, I felt absolutely nothing for any of the characters in this movie.  Tom Cruise played a robot-like clone, not unusual considering most of his characters are faceless emotionless blobs in recent years.  Last time he played a character that I liked was in Interview with a Vampire, so I wasn't surprised at the lackluster performance in Oblivion.  Everyone just seemed to walk from one scene to the next, feeling nothing and portraying NONE of the emotional hell that the situation would call for had it been real-life.I am astounded; as graphics increase, acting ability decreases on the same scale.

reviewText: Oblivion is kind of like a cross between the gloriously clean visual style of 2001: A Space Odyssey with the more involved, exciting simplicity of Star Wars: A New Hope. The film is simply beautiful in its sparse aesthetic design, elegant technology and breathtaking cinematography. And of course the musical score, as well, with involvement from M83. Tom Cruise is very good in this, as a character who involves the viewer but never overwhelms the story or setting. If you have only read a brief synopsis or saw the trailer, you may be in for some surprises upon actually watching this film, which is a nice thing to be able to say.In an age where science fiction films are often cluttered, messy and frenetic (which can be good in some cases, granted) Oblivion is a refreshingly different creature. Watching it really feels like taking a breath of fresh air. If you find the idea of a film that combines the relatively clean visualizations of the best prestige sci-fi of the past, with modern visual effects and a dystopian story that is not prohibitively depressing, then this is one to check out.

reviewText: If you enjoy good stories with a bit of mystery and action, sit back and enjoy this movie.This is a well told story that takes its time, the actors are good, the story and plot is nice, the effects are well done but do not overshadow the story.  This is a movie more for adults than tiny kids.  This movie does not spoon feed the audience every detail, the movie drops you into a situation and tells a story.On the actors... great job!  Some of the actors just weirded me out and I never quite knew what they were going to do.  Others were just solid performances.On the effects... I loved the drones.  The way the movie portrayed them, I felt nervous when they were in a scene.Overall..  this movie is head and shoulders above much of the utter crud that is out there.
summary: Quality Sci-Fi - good story, NOT shoot-em up go go go action
Title: N/A

reviewText: I mean... it's Tom Cruise. Any movie he's in, he's never anyone else but Tom Cruise. Rarely is he in a very deep or thought-provoking movie in this genre. (vanilla sky is one exception that comes to mind) Oblivion is good fun as "sci-fi lite" for when you want a fix without a labyrinthine plot. Basically the polar opposite of something like Blade Runner or Children of Men. (side note: I'm not sure I can name a movie where Tom Cruise disappeared into a role... he's always the same, good or bad you always just see him.)Having said that, this movie has visual style to burn and is not without "twists" in the story. Everything is telegraphed prior to revelation and thus not much is terribly shocking for anyone that treads the science fiction waters regularly, but it is a solid movie. That's not to say that some won't miss those tells and be thus surprised at times... it is a well done movie with good talent all around. (yes, even Tom Cruise most of the time) Most reviews were overly harsh and similar to 2010's Tron Legacy, this was raked over the coals without giving it a chance. (Which may be more telling that you first think as they both were directed by Joseph Kosinski) It is allot of fun, especially when watching with others and the aforementioned popcorn. It is enjoyable.I did mention style, and it truly oozes a visual flair that makes the world come alive. (or bleakly dead, depending on how you look at it) It comes from a comic (ahem, graphic novel!) and keeps that saturated look to it, which is a great feast on larger TVs. It is worth Buying Blurray over DVD without question. Note that this is not style over substance (say like Ultraviolet or Chronicles of Riddick) and this still runs plot circles around those types of movie. More-so, when stood up against most things from Marvel (which are firmly planted in the 'unsurprising-but-enjoyable' popcorn category) and everything from Michael Bay (which is in the 'throw-money-at-the-screen-and-don't-even-bother-to-stitch-it-together-intelligently' category) then this movie looks positively stellar.Bottom Line: If you like action-sci-fi with great visual flair and decent story then this is worth seeing.

reviewText: I really liked this movie.Tom Cruise plays a man two weeks away from completing his maintenance duties on an earth outpost. Earth has basically been demolished by aliens, and he's living with a women who was posted there with him. There almost ready to go back to civilization on another planet (Titan) when twists and turns ensue, but I can't be more specific than that without giving spoilers.Here's why I liked it:- The story was creative, interesting and full of unexpected twists. Lots of mystery.- The characters were fairly well developed. You're led to care about them.- The movie held my attention throughout, and had that "edge of your seat" feel at times.- The cast was fantastic.- The effects were realistic, and the story believable and interesting.I did feel that the script could have had you caring about the characters more intensely. Still, it was very entertaining, and it's one I'll definitely want to watch it again.I recommend it to all scifi fans.

reviewText: All my many reviews focus solely upon the actual quality of the film from Standard Def DVD quality to the higher standard set for Blu Ray. Summaries of the plot and opinions of the story line and acting can be found in the majority of the other reviews so I do not want to be redundant.Keep in mind, however, that the quality of what you see and hear is also dependent upon the quality of the TV monitor you are watching on as well as the home theater set up you are using. The monitor I use is a fairly new Panasonic ZT 65" plasma and the amps, speakers, cables, BluRay player and Surround Processor I use are hi end esoteric gear to provide me with a more realistic and objective perspective.VIDEO....The video transfer is nothing short of excellent.  Colors are very realistic and contrast is excellent allowing you to see very small detailing in the background and foreground.  In a few of the darker and shadow scenes, details were not lost. Blacks are fully deep and no banding can be seen in either the blacks or sky shots which is often where you would see such banding.  Color saturation has been boosted a touch but nothing that distracts from the imaging.  At no point did I notice any CGI haloing or artificiality within the image itself.  Being a newer film, the blu ray was free from artifacts or dropouts of any kind.  Mbps rate stayed in the steady mid thirties.  Even this could have been improved without the 3 video ads and 2 movie previews.( Will get to those later)AUDIO....So glad that production houses are finally starting to include a 7.1 audio mix.  This is the first Blu Ray I have seen that actually defaults to the 7.1 audio.  If your system is still a 5.1 system, not to fret, the additional 6th and 7th channels will be muxed to feed into your 4th and 5th rear channels without any issues.  The lossless DTS HD MA 7.1 audio mix is quite excellent with a wide use of discreet directionality to your surrounds with much panning between the front and rear stages to create an enveloping film and aural experience.  Your LFE channel will not be ignored as there is plenty in this film that will keep it occupied.  Dialogue is clear and transparent and foley effects absolutely delineated for your ears.  There will be no need to play roller coaster with your remote's volume control once you set it to your liking.EXTRAS...The one clearly negative thing about this Blu Ray is that there are 2 ads and 3 previews of other films. You are paying for their advertising which takes up room on the Blu Ray calling for even more video compression in order to fit it all in. Who wants to pay for an  advertisement ? Not me, I'd rather have an improved video transfer with less compression.The real extras are deleted scenes which were good enough to make for an extended version and a 'Making of' documentary divided up into several parts covering the creation of the ships, stunt work which Tom Cruise takes pride in doing, the inception of the film and more.  Additionally, there is a separate musical score you can listen to.The digital copy that is included allows you to download via Ultra Violet, which I do not like, or to iTunes which I do.  I am glad that I have the choice to go one way or the other with this.This is an FX laden Science Fiction film.  To be honest, I must say that I was disappointed in the movie itself.  I was thinking that it was a Sci Fi 'chick flick' but I know many will disagree.  Effects are great but a movie should be about the characters and storyline and not FX.  Never the less, the production values of this Blu Ray are outstanding and well worth purchasing  despite the included advertisements.I do hope that this review, which focused solely upon the quality of the actual transfer to Blu Ray has been of some help to you in deciding your purchase. All of my reviews are of this nature and I hope they can be of HELP to you as well.Thanks for reading.
